—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In view of the fact that many pensioners are very concerned about the prospect of the Government's proposal to limit the money they can keep in non-interest bearing bank accounts before having their pensions and fringe benefits cut and bearing in mind that some pensioners use this system to obtain the pension and the fringe benefits, can the Minister assure the Senate that pensioners who are in genuine need will not be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals in this regard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made a number of statements on this matter. I have tried to make it clear that pensioners who are in genuine need will not be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals. I think a deal of the concern in this matter has arisen from the fact that some pensioners have drawn the conclusion that the only asset they can have is the $2,000 or $3,000 referred to in the second reading speech in this chamber on the Social Services Amendment Bill, whereas in fact the reference there was to any additional amount held over and above other assets of the pensioner which are returning income. I have issued a number of statements recently making clear the different levels of income which can be received by a pensioner without it affecting his pension or fringe benefits. It is not proposed that there should be any change in those limits.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment a single pensioner may get $20 a week in income and a married couple may get $34.50 a week and still be entitled to the full rate of pension. The effect of the tapered income test is to ensure that one can then receive a part pension over a quite wide range of incomes. For example, a married couple may receive a part pension when they have a non-pension income of up to $266 a week. There is a very large range of incomes over which a pension or part pension can be received and there is no proposal that that should be altered.

With respect to the fringe benefits, I have said in the Senate before that I think that they are probably more critical for many pensioners. There are existing income limits with respect to those benefits. A single pensioner can have investments or something returning income of up to $40 a week without losing the fringe benefits and a married couple can have up to $68 a week in earnings or other income before they lose their entitlement to the pensioner health benefit card. Amounts which are held in an interest bearing account are amounts over and above amounts which produce that sort of income. It is a fact, however, that some pensioners do keep very large sums of money in non-interest bearing accounts. I have had some quite extraordinary reports over recent months of people holding amounts as high as $80,000 or $50,000 in interest free accounts simply to obtain fringe benefits. That, of course, is a very nice gift to the organisation that is holding the money because there is certainly no value to the pensioner compared with the interest forgone in that situation. It is indeed a field in which, I think, many pensioners are worse off because they arrange their affairs in a way which reduces their income far more than they would lose in pension benefits. The real difficulty in this area, as I have said before, is the fringe benefit situation. It is a situation which I have under examination. I would like to see that problem reduced for pensioners, if not entirely removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It relates to the industrial dispute between his Department and the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association in which officers have been stood down in Victoria and other places because they have refused to do work on overpayments ahead of other departmental duties. Is the Minister aware that many of the staff who have officially stopped work and are therefore, not being paid are anxious, nevertheless, to attend their offices in the next day or so in order to issue emergency cheques and process continuation claims so that pensioners and beneficiaries will not suffer? Will they be allowed to do this work so that payments can be made to claimants? If not, what action does the Minister propose to prevent unpaid staff from doing such urgent work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one inaccuracy in the particulars which were put forward in the question asked by Senator Grimes which I think I should clear up. He suggested that the bans related to a refusal to do certain work on overpayments ahead of other duties, whereas in fact there has been a simple ban on the carrying out of certain work. It is not a question of whether the work is ahead of other duties, although the union has chosen to try to present the position in the light in which Senator Grimes put it in his question. The fact of the matter is that for a period of 12 months members of the union refused to do part of the work for which they are employed. Notwithstanding repeated requests, those bans were retained in New South Wales and Victoria. That is the central difficulty in this dispute.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the performance of unpaid work by officers, I am aware that a number of them, after they have been stood down or gone off the job, have returned to complete certain work in the interests of clients. As I understand it, that represents a desire not to see clients ill-affected. However, I distinguish between positive actions of that sort and the sorts of threats which were made in the motion which was carried in New South Wales yesterday which refers to additional and varying action at the work place being intensified and random rolling stoppages being continued. I have no doubt that the reference to additional and varying action at the work place relates to the sort of obstructionist procedures which are set out in the booklet produced by Mr Bunn, to which I referred in the Senate last week. I make it quite clear that those officers who engage in activity which obstructs the work of the Department will be required to desist.

A further threat has been made that a regional office will be opened by union action. It is obviously quite unacceptable to have groups of shop stewards indicating which offices shall be opened and which shall not. The work of my Department, which is being carried on by the majority of officers, who have remained at their posts, will continue for the benefit of clients. It is not possible for the Government to accept that decisions will be made by committees of shop stewards as to what offices shall be opened and when they shall be opened. If that is the sort of co-operation Senator Grimes suggested in his question, it is the sort of co-operation the Government simply cannot accept. Although it is put forward in the guise of co-operation it is, in fact, merely an attempt to take the running of the Department out of the hands of the management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps it should be called a restating of the original question. The answer Senator Chaney gave demonstrated the attitude that he has taken on this dispute all along in his refusal to consult and everything else. I ask the Minister: Will officers of the Department be allowed to return to perform their tasks of issuing emergency cheques and processing continuation claims, unpaid, so that payments can be made to claimants who need them? If not, what action does he propose to prevent the staff from doing this unpaid work? One might also ask when he is going to talk to the union to get something done in this escalating dispute.

—Any officer who is prepared to work according to the directions of the management of the Department in the office in which he is employed will have the opportunity to work. Any officer who believes that he can work as he wishes, when he wishes, doing what he wishes will not be tolerated within the Department. That is quite a straightforward matter. As I said in August, I am more than happy to talk to the union when the bans are lifted. I think it is time that the Opposition declared whether it agrees that a trade union is entitled to demand what the level of staffing will be, what work will be performed within a department and what programs will be introduced by a government. I do not believe that any government, or indeed any opposition, can embrace the proposition that a trade union is entitled to take those matters into its own hands. Certainly, that is not a case where the Government would tolerate that happening. As far as my talking to the union is concerned, I again make it quite clear-as I said in August and as I have repeated over and over again-that I am very happy to talk to the union when the bans are lifted. I do not believe that the Government talks to the union under the threat of the sort which has been imposed by this trade union.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask whether he has been able to obtain answers to the questions I asked him on 8 September and 28 October? The Minister will recollect that these questions concerned the use of pancreatic tissue taken from either living or dead babies proceeding from women whose intention was to kill them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I have the answers to all the sections of both the questions asked by Senator Martyr. I do have some information. I am able to advise honourable senators that there is no human foetal-

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I take it that the question is on the Notice Paper. Senator Martyr should merely refer to the number of the question without again asking the question. If the question is still on the Notice Paper then that question should be given in the normal way and not at Question Time. It should be asked after Question Time and not right now.

—There is no point of order. This matter has been raised so many times in this chamber. If we work on the proposition as propounded by Senator Georges then this could completely stifle Question Time. This would not be in the interests of this chamber.
—Mr President, speaking to the point of order, that-
—Order! I have ruled on the point of order.

—I understand there are no questions on this matter on notice at all. It is simply an inability of Senator Georges to comprehend what is going on. There is no human foetal tissue bank in Australia at the present time nor is there any intention to establish one. Experimentation on foetal pancreatic tissue to test its viability for transplantation-the idea of that was to try to reverse juvenile onset diabetes, a serious illness in children-is very much in the developmental stage. No transplant of human foetal tissue into diabetic patients has so far been undertaken. All experimentation to date has involved animals only.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Martyr previously has raised the question of a tissue bank in the Australian Capital Territory. The only work being carried out in the Australian Capital Territory in this development field is by Dr K. Lafferty of the John Curtin School of Medical Research. Dr Lafferty has received a grant from the Tertiary Education Commission for this research. Accordingly, in case there is any other answer that can be given, a copy of Senator Martyr's question has now been referred to the Minister for Education for a response. But in view of the very real concern in the research community and in the public generally concerning human tissue transplants the Minister for Health has referred the question to the Attorney-General for his consideration as to whether the matter could be referred to the Australian Law Reform Commission. If the matter is so referred the National Health and Medical Research Council would be happy to refer to the Commission. In the meantime I think there is no basis for real or sustainable concern of the kind which has exercised Senator Martyr.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question concerning banking profits. I address it to him, not in a banking sense but in a political sense; hence I ask him rather than Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I draw the Minister's attention to last week's announcement by the Bank of New South Wales that its annual profit had increased from $124m to $165m during last year, which is a rise of 33.3 per cent in one year. Also, did the Minister see the announcement by the Australia and New Zeland Banking Group Limited that its profits increased from $136m to $175m during the same period, a more modest rise of only 29 per cent in one year? Other banks in the process of merging have also reported recently the following profit increases: 33.7 per cent for the National Bank of Australasia Limited, 27.1 per cent for the Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Limited and 19.3 per cent for the Commercial Bank of Australia Limited. In view of those announcements, will the Government urgently review the Australian interest rate structure which makes it possible for the banks to achieve those record profit levels? In particular, will the Treasurer act immediately to reduce the savage interest rates which currently apply to home buyers' loans? Finally, how can this Government possibly justify a situation in which banks are charging home buyers interest rates of 17 to 20 per cent on home loans but are allowed to have the gall to achieve such massive increases in real profits?

—I have not seen the stated profits of the banks and, not having seen them, I cannot comment on them. It would be necessary to take into consideration the relationship to shareholders' investments and the return on investments to understand the real implications of the profits. The rest of the honourable senator's question asks whether the Government will undertake certain things with regard to interest rates, particularly interest rates on home purchase loans. This is a policy matter and I will therefore direct it to the attention of the Treasurer. As honourable senators know, the whole question of interest rates and of banking and bank finance is now under review. The Goverment has directed its budgetary policy fundamentally towards two things, namely, getting the inflation rate down and suppressing interest rates. There are aleady signs that the policy is having an effect on interest rates. This is the main direction that one should take in order to alleviate the burden of interest charges upon people. There are two main ways to help people. If we want to help people who want to own houses, the first thing we should do is to get the inflation rate down and keep it down because the cost of a house -
—You have been saying that for five years.

—Indeed, we have been saying it for five years. We have brought the inflation rate down from the huge rate it was at under the Whitlam Government to one of the more modest rates of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development today. In order to help people to own their homes one aims at suppressing inflation-we have been significantly successful in that regard-and in suppressing interest rates. On that basis, at the moment the Government has under study the whole area of banking and interest rates. In due course it will announce its policy.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I apologise to the Leader of the Government in the Senate for my lack of intellectual capacity in not understanding a word he just said in answering my question. I ask my supplementary question on the basis of a couple of phrases I heard him say about helping people and the comment that profits have to be related to funds invested and shareholders' funds. I ask him this question in simple terms, and I ask him to answer it in equally simple terms that I can understand: On the figures that I have quoted, is it not a fact that the Bank of New South Wales made $41m more profit this year than last year? Is it not a simple fact that the ANZ Banking Group made $39m more profit this year than last year? I simply ask: Is there not in those figures, in the Government's view, room for the banking system to manoeuvre to reduce interest rates to home buyers?

—I am sorry that Senator Chipp did not understand my answer. What I said was that I had not seen the statement of the profits. Therefore, I do not know whether the figures he gave are right or wrong. His arithmetic I can confirm, if the figures are so. I said that I would need to see the profits and the rate of investment. I repeat: The way to help home owners is the way in which this Government, more than that of any country in the world, has helped home ownership, that is, to get the cost of inflation down and put a brake upon interest rates. That would be of greater benefit than any other matter. I also undertook to refer the remainder of the question to the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that last week the Department of Social Security issued 21,000 fewer cheques in New South Wales than normal? This was asserted by Mr Jim Pearce, senior industrial officer of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The item raised by the honourable senator is another example of the misinformation which has flowed in this area. The fact is that last Friday an ACOA media release was made about the number of cheques issued in the week. It said that in the week ending 20 October 1981 the number of cheques issued had fallen to 49,000, a massive 30 per cent reduction. I assume that that was meant to relate to the week ending 20 November since the union was concerned about the effect of the strike on the issue of cheques. It was a very odd news release to make because the figures for the week, of course, were not available at the time it was made, the week consisting of five days and not of four. The suggestion that there had been this great drop was, therefore, previous, and on the same day I issued a statement pointing out that the Friday figures were not yet available and giving an estimate that the figure would be in excess of 65,000 for the week. In fact the advice I have had this morning is that the number of cheques issued for the whole week exceeded 70,000 and was in excess of the average of the preceding three weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a real difficulty in dealing with this dispute that there has been what appears to be a positive campaign of misinformation. It is sometimes difficult, even when the correct information is issued almost immediately, to ensure that the people who are reporting on the matter have both sets of information before them. Indeed, in a discussion on Friday with someone from the Australian Broadcasting Commission the view was put to a member of my staff: 'We are entitled to put the views of the other side'. I respectfully suggest that in matters such as this we are dealing not with views but with facts. It is not a bad idea to get the facts straight so that the public can be a judge of these matters. The fact is that last week the number of cheques issued was larger than the average number of cheques issued in the previous three weeks, notwithstanding the disruption caused by a minority of the people in my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns Aspect House. Was the takeover of the operations of Aspect House by the Tasmanian Mental Health Services Commission a condition of the provision by the Commonwealth of a once-only $50,000 grant to the Tasmanian Government for the centre? Prior to the announcement of the joint review of the operations of Aspect House, did the then responsible Tasmanian Minister suggest that the Tasmanian Mental Health Services Commission take over the operations of Aspect House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter about which a number of questions have been raised in the Senate. There was very understandable public interest because the Aspect House matter affected the care of a group of children, and a group of parents, for whom there would be very great public sympathy. There was, in my view, excellent co-operation from the Tasmanian Government in dealing with what was a very difficult situation. I remind the Senate that originally, as part of the family support scheme which is funded by the Commonwealth, it was agreed that we would provide $60,000, I think it was, to a group of people to provide respite care for severely mentally retarded children. That got under way some time after the original approval. It became apparent very early that the level of expenditure by those operating Aspect House was substantially in excess of the funds which had been granted. There was a further difficulty in that the funds had been made available for a one-year project only and clearly the parents were concerned about the long term future.

ANSWER.PARA: There was agreement between the two governments that fundamentally the matter was the concern of the Mental Health Services Commission rather than my Department or the Community Welfare Department in Tasmania. Therefore, after the review had been undertaken-a review in which both governments participated-there was an agreement that the Mental Health Services Commission would be responsible for the respite care of these children. Because there were financial difficulties for the Tasmanian Government in immediately assuming full responsibility, the Commonwealth agreed that it would make what I think Senator Harradine described as-and what was described at the time as-a one-off grant of $50,000 to the Tasmanian Government to assist it in picking up that responsibility. At the same time it was agreed that the Tasmanian Government would also make available funds of a similar order. I have the Press release which was put out at that time and some of the correspondence undertaken at that time. I indicated that we would be providing funds in the following terms:

. . . the Commonwealth will provide an amount of $50,000 for the rest of this financial year as a one off grant in order to assist in the provision of care to run a service for severely handicapped children with behavioural difficulties. This is on the basis that the Tasmanian Government will also provide $50,000 for the Mental Health Services Commission to take over the respite care service at Aspect House that was previously operated by Colony 47.

I should mention that it is my understanding that the premises on which this was conducted were actually the premises of the Mental Health Services Commission. Unfortunately, I think there is some continuing dispute because some of the parents are not satisfied that that is the best course to be followed. I can say only that after very careful examination, firstly by review of the program and secondly, by the Tasmanian authorities, this was thought to be the most appropriate course to follow to provide the sort of care originally sought for these children, namely, respite care which would enable their parents to have some break from the very heavy responsibilities they have for the care of such children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of a statement that Telecom Australia was considering charging higher call fees instead of large capital contributions for digital radio and satellite connected telephones? Is the Minister aware that the very high cost of connection charged by Telecom-around $20,000 per connection-arises from the sheer incompetence of Telecom? For example, one subscriber has advised me that for a standard radio telephone connection six visits, 12 vehicles and 20 men were required for a maximum of 20 man-hours work. Will the Minister issue a firm directive to Telecom to provide a service to rural subscribers at a reasonable and competitive cost or vacate the field to private industry?
—I have taken that, perhaps incorrectly, as a statement of concern rather than a question. I think it would be better if I referred it to my colleague for considered and detailed reply.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Health consider a resumption of funding for anti-tuberculosis measures due to the alarming increase in the incidence of TB, especially in disadvantaged groups throughout the community, namely, pensioners and the unemployed? Has the tuberculosis rate for unemployed people risen from the level of one per cent in 1971 to 11.5 per cent in 1980? Has the tuberculosis rate for pensioners risen from 19.5 per cent in 1971 to 33.2 per cent in 1980?

—I do not know whether Senator Jones was here last week, but I answered then a question in some detail about the incidence of tuberculosis in Australia. I was able to advise the Senate in that answer that there is no truth in the assertion that there are very high rates of tuberculosis in either of the groups mentioned by Senator Jones, that is, unemployed people or pensioners. I was able to point out last week that probably Australia has one of the lowest tuberculosis rates in the world, that the overall community rate is still extremely low, and that as our population has aged a bit and those who have suffered from tuberculosis in years past have aged, the elderly population seems to have had concentrated in it the residual effects of tuberculosis. I refer the honourable senator to the Hansard report of last week's question and answer. I think he will agree that the cause for his concern-it is quite properly held following earlier reports-is not based on fact and for that reason there is no real need to re-examine the introduction of special programs.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. On 29 September Mr Anthony issued a media release concerning Australia's joining the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code. In view of this statement, which mentions that Australia's acceptance of the Code would not preclude the Government from introducing new export incentive schemes not inconsistent with the Code, can the Minister advise whether the Government has considered, or is considering, any alteration or addition to existing schemes that are designed to promote and facilitate Australian exporters competing in the many areas of growing potential trade? If successful, would not these additions allow Australia to increase its global imports accordingly?

—As I understand it, the current export incentive schemes are scheduled to operate until 30 June 1983. The Industries Assistance Commission is currently examining what changes should be made to the schemes and what alternative measures, if any, should be introduced. Any alterations or additions will be made only after the Government has considered the IAC report. Should Australia's exports increase for any reason, including the operation of export incentives, there would be a positive impact on Australia's ability to absorb imports. If there is any further information that my colleague, the Minister for Trade and Resources, may wish to add, I will seek it for the honourable senator.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, relates to the reported intention of the Northern Territory Government to enact legislation which would diminish the power of the Sacred Sites Protection Authority and transfer to the Ministers of the Northern Territory Government the power to register sacred sites. As Aborigines are specifically excluded from the matters over which the Ministers of the Northern Territory are to have executive authority under Regulation 4 (2) of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978, does the Minister agree that the registration of Aboriginal sacred sites is a matter over which the Northern Territory Government has no executive power? Does the Minister agree that any attempts by that Government to transfer the power to register sacred sites to its Ministers would be invalid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of the honourable senator's question seeks a legal opinion which, in accordance with Standing Order 99, I do not care to offer. I think her question arose out of an article in the Age newspaper this morning. I understand that the authority over sacred sites rests both with the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976-clause 69 of that Act relates specifically to sacred sites-and a Northern Territory Act, which is complementary to the land rights Act, called the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Act 1978 (Northern Territory). Both Acts operate for the proper protection of Aboriginal sites. The newspaper report is not completely accurate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has written to the Prime Minister and to the three land councils advising his intention to amend the complementary legislation, the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Act 1978 (Northern Territory). Mr Everingham has indicated his Government's desire to introduce legislation very soon into the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and to allow it to lie on the table for some months in order to invite public comment with a view to having it considered some time during the first session in 1982. In other words, there is no intention to proceed to any precipitate action. I am given to understand that the Northern Territory Government believes that, by adopting this course of action, a comprehensive and public consideration of the issues will ensue.

I have not seen any detailed form of the proposed legislation. I do not know in detail what it will contain. If, when it is tabled, there are problems which are identified as a result of the public discussion and if those problems cannot be resolved by reference to procedures which are already provided for under existing legislation-I refer the honourable senator back to clause 69 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act-there may be some case for considering amendments to existing legislation. I want to assure honourable senators and the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory that the Commonwealth will not support any proposed amendments dealing with sacred sites unless there has been full and comprehensive consultation with the Aboriginal people through the land councils and that adequate opportunity has been given for the councils to make known their views, both to the Northern Territory Government and to the Commonwealth Governments. At the moment, all I have to go on is a general statement. I am still waiting to see the form of legislation which may be tabled for public discussion in the Legislative Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. As a positive gesture towards fostering closer links between Australia and New Zealand, will the Government consider paying Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances to Australian students who are studying in New Zealand?

—As I understand it, under the Student Assistance Act, the Minister for Education has authority to approve courses for the purposes of benefits under TEAS. This authority, in fact, does not extend to approval of courses at overseas institutions. However, a student undertaking an approved course at an Australian institution may receive TEAS to undertake part of the course at an overseas institution provided he remains enrolled at the Australian institution for the period and the work undertaken at the overseas institution forms part of his course at the Australian institution. That answer may not cover totally what Senator Watson has in mind. That, as I understand it, is the limit for today. If Senator Watson is referring to a student going wholly to a New Zealand institution and being enrolled at that institution, as I understand it, at the moment that situation is outside our policy. I will refer it as a policy matter to my colleague in another place for consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I point out to the Minister that on 15 October I asked her a question relating to conflicting Press reports about battles being fought between Organisasi Papua Merdoka-OPM-forces in Irian Jaya and Indonesian Government forces. I asked the Minister on that occasion:

QUESTION.PARA: In the interests of information, will the Minister ask the Australian intelligence personnel operating in this region to make a factual report on these events so that both this Parliament and the Australian people can be made fully aware of just what is happening in our near north?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs replied to me by way of a written answer. He said:

It has been the practice of successive Governments not to comment on any matters relating to intelligence and security. It will not be possible, therefore, to provide a report of the kind requested by Senator Primmer.

I point out to the Minister that I was not seeking any security or intelligence reports whatsoever. I was purely seeking some information as to whether battles had been fought in West Irian during the period August to September. In light of that, I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that an Indonesian Hercules aircraft was shot at and forced to land at Jayapura airport on 23 July 1981? As a consequence, were Indonesian commandoes flown into the area? Did they subsequently wipe out the villages of Bramali, Aip, Sabeap, Skorip and Aimbai? What was the fate of those people unable to flee these villages, particularly females? Is it a fact that a battle between OPM and Indonesian forces took place in the Jayapura sub-district of Genyem-Nimbooran at 5 a.m. on 1 August this year? Are there any figures available of the casualties suffered by both sides? Did OPM forces raid a prison and a police station in this action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I noted the response that was given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the earlier question. In view of the detail of the question now being posed, I suggest that it be placed on notice to see whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs is able to give any information in response to the various points that have now been raised.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the Estimates Committee D report to the Senate under 'Item 4-Civil Defence', where the Committee determined that no employee in the Natural Disasters Organisation was employed specifically to plan for defence against nuclear attack. With increasing emphasis being placed on Australia's civil defence preparedness in the event of a nuclear and other forms of attack, what action will be taken, or is being taken, to ensure that the Natural Disasters Organisation is appropriately organised to plan for and cope with a nuclear attack?

—Although it is correct that no employee of the Natural Disasters Organisation is employed specifically to plan for defence against nuclear attack, the activities of the Organisation encompass the sort of planning that would be appropriate for a nuclear disaster. Preparation for large scale natural disasters involves the same sort of organisation and planning as would be required in nuclear attack. This sort of activity can be rapidly and readily adapted to nuclear emergencies whereas planning specifically for defence against nuclear attack cannot be readily adapted to large-scale natural disasters. The Natural Disasters Organisation, together with State emergency services, co-ordinates planning for large-scale natural disasters.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it a fact that the Ranger operation in the Northern Territory has been closed down because of a defect in the tailings dam? Is it a fact that, as reported, the defect was noticed on 9 November but was not reported either to the Department or to the Supervising Scientist? Since this is at least the second occasion within a few months on which a major incident has not been reported as required, what action does the Government intend to take to discipline the companies involved and to tighten security within the industry?

—I am concerned at the report. If indeed there have been negligence and a failure to report, I would regard it as a significant matter. My understanding is that the Northern Territory Government has ordered the shutdown of the Ranger mill pending investigation by the Northern Territory authorities into reports that tailings had been exposed in the Ranger tailings dam earlier this month. As Senator Robertson would well know, the authorisations require that the tailings should be covered by two metres of water to allow the radon gas to permeate slowly so that it will cause no troubles. Apparently there has been a breach of the authorisations. I can only say that, if this is so, my Government and, I am sure, the Northern Territory Government would regard this seriously and appropriate steps will be taken.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the last report of the Bureau of Transport Economics from which can properly be drawn the conclusion that Western Australia's share of future Federal road grants is recommended to be 8.3 per cent-coincidently, very similar to our percentage of population which is 8.7 per cent. I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that Western Australia has 19.6 per cent of the nation's road length, occupies one-third of the Australian continent and is responsible for 20 per cent of the nation's export income wealth and that much of Western Australia's recent national roads have been constructed for the purpose of opening up and servicing our export wealth, will the Minister undertake to ensure that these factors are taken into consideration in the future determination of the distribution of road funds rather than the emphasis being placed on population and vehicle numbers?

—About two weeks ago a similar question was asked by, I think, Senator Bjelke-Petersen in connection with Queensland. She was complaining that Queensland was doing particularly badly under the present formula. While I cannot confirm the figures outlined in the Bureau of Transport Economics report, it is clear that the Government has in mind taking into account the kinds of factors which I think Senator Crichton-Browne has referred to in his question. The Minister, in reply to that previous question, did undertake to Senator Bjelke-Petersen to bear in mind those factors. At this stage I can do no more than that but I will undertake to refer the question to the Minister for Transport and obtain any further information which he might care to give.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What effect would a substantial rise in domestic interest rates have on the Government's loan raising program? I refer to interest rates in view of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, which recommends deregulation of interest rates in Australia. Is the proportion of funds the Government borrows within Australia likely to decrease if domestic interest rates rise? What would be the implications for Australia's balance of payments situation if the Government borrowed more heavily from overseas sources than it has in the past? Is this the reason the Government is looking to the possibility of raising overseas loans from sources such as the Saudis, rather than from traditional sources in Europe and Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the last part of the question can be discounted in view of my response earlier today from the Treasurer. The other parts of the question are rather hypothetical. The Campbell Inquiry report is under study and no decisions have been taken on its recommendations. I do not think that any conclusions ought to be drawn with regard to the mix of borrowing that the Federal Government would undertake. Many factors are taken into account when looking at the requirements of government but I think I ought to state again that what we have been trying to do is to see that we make as little intrusion as possible on the borrowing market by containing our expenditure in order not to have some of the difficulties that otherwise could arise. However, with the hypothetical questions that have been raised and the inference that has been drawn from some of the Campbell recommendations, I think people ought to await a response from the Government on the Campbell Inquiry report.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DUMPING OF INDUSTRIAL WASTE AT SEA

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment reconcile the Government's responsibilities for the implementation of the 200-mile off-shore fishing zone with the practices epitomised in a few days by the action of the Victorian Government in utilising a Japanese tanker to dump 3,000 tonnes of industrial waste? I do not simply point the finger at the Victorian Government; I refer to any cosy arrangements that any State governments may have. This is now a different ball game with the creation of the 200-mile fishing zone and our United Nation convention obligations in that area.

—I believe that the matter referred to by Senator Mulvihill involves the dumping of some material by a Victorian firm-Smorgons. I understand it is the result of wood processing so the waste material contains some wood products-sodium ligno-sulphate and other substances resulting from wood processing. I am informed that after consultation with appropriate State and Commonwealth authorities the Commonwealth Department of Home Affairs and Environment has raised no objection to the trial dumping-I emphasise trial dumping-of some 3,000 tonnes of wood pulp residues 150 to 250 nautical miles off the Australian coast. There is a proviso to that approval and that is that the operation must be carried out in accordance with the relevant law. That law is the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, which honourable senators will know received its assent a few months ago. The waste contains only minute quantities of heavy metals, such as mercury, cadmium and lead, and I am advised that the dumping will not cause any adverse effects on the marine environment. While the dumping is being carried out in accordance with the Act which controls sea dumping, the Department sees no objection to it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I ask: In view of the $1.6m subsidy by the Federal Government to the Australian Ballet Foundation would it not be justifiable for the Government to have some influence on the composition of the Board of the Australian Ballet Foundation, particularly as the method of funding the Ballet adopted by the Government effectively prevents the Australian Council from having any influence at all on the operations of the Australian Ballet? Is it a fact that the present Board is a sort of self-perpetuating hierarchy elected by the members of the Ballet Foundation, who number 211 at the moment? Does the Minister consider it to be desirable to have a suitable mix of business people and practitioners of the arts on the Board of the Australian Ballet Foundation in view of the national and international importance of the Australian Ballet? Can the Minister say specifically how many of the 13 present members of the Board of the Australian Ballet Foundation have, firstly, any professional experience of ballet and, secondly, any professional experience of any performing art form?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the composition of any board or company, and that would include that of the Australian Ballet Foundation, is made up following an election by the members of that board or company. Under the Victorian Companies Act there are approximately 250 members of the Australian Ballet Foundation and these 250 members elected the current board. An Australia Council condition of grant for any company receiving more than $50,000 per year is that the company should have open membership, and the Australian Ballet Foundation does have open membership. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security but also concerns the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. When will consideration of the particular requests put at that time, and well received by Ministers, be concluded? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, very familiar with the matter raised by the honourable senator. He is right in saying that it is a concern not merely of me and my Department but also of my friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume and his Department. I think in terms of current consideration one can also include the previous Minister who was at the meeting with the people from the Pitjantjatjara council in this building about 18 months ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The CDEP is one of a number of mechanisms which have been used to enable Aboriginal groups to have some alternative to unemployment benefit or 'sit-down' money. The CDEP is a mechanism whereby the Department of Aboriginal Affairs provides the equivalent amount of unemployment benefit which would otherwise be payable, plus some small additional loading for administration, plant and so on. Work to the value of that amount is then provided in the community to improve the general situation of the community.

Senator Teague, who has taken a very close interest in this matter, is right in describing it in benign terms, although its effectiveness has varied from place to place. I think it has been very successful in the Torres Strait. I think it has been sometimes successful and sometimes less successful in Central Australia. It has been very useful in the north and in such places as Elcho Island. So whilst it is not an unmixed result, yes, there have been many favourable aspects of CDEP. In addition, my Department has been involved in some arrangements for the bulk payment of individual benefits, particularly in some northern Western Australian communities, the general objective of which is similar to the objective of CDEP. There have been both administrative difficulties and some difficulties of principle. Some people would take the view that because social security benefits are an individual entitlement it is not appropriate to provide mechanisms which interfere with the direct receipt of those benefits by beneficiaries. But in fact it would be the general view of the Government with its experience of CDEP that there is benefit in communities which wish to follow that track in having something like CDEP available to them.

The discussions which have followed the meeting referred to by Senator Teague in his question are discussions which have been extensive and have involved the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, my own department and the Department of Finance. There have been several discussions between Ministers over the last month. I can only say to Senator Teague that it is my expectation that a decision will be taken shortly as to the path we will follow with respect to the further development of CDEP. In the meantime funds will continue to be provided in support of the existing schemes through programs under the control of my colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
