DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, I present a report on the Committee's reference on Australia's forestry and forest products industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Mr President, this report is the culmination of a long and involved inquiry. The forestry and forest products industries cover a diverse range of economic activities, and the difficulties experienced by the industries in recent years are exemplified by the fact that more than 30 public inquiries into various aspects of their operations have been conducted in the last 10 years. So in this report the Committee has attempted to draw together the threads of all these various inquiries and reports. The Committee notes with concern that many valuable and well-founded recommendations of those inquiries have not been taken up and it seriously questions the merit of conducting further inquiries while recommendations such as those to which it refers go unheeded.

Under the Commonwealth Constitution, the responsibility for forest management rests with the States. Accordingly, it was not surprising that we were often asked why a Committee of the Senate should become involved. In accepting the reference the Committee believed it to be a proper function of the Senate to investigate areas involving all States' policies and where, perhaps inadvertently, situations arise which are not in the best interests of Australia-wide industries, nor of the nation as a whole. In this context the Committee found that in Australia's quest for national self-sufficiency in wood production each State has also set about achieving self-sufficiency within its own borders. While the goal of national self-sufficiency implies a considerable degree of specialisation and each-way trade between the States, current State policies fail to ensure that this is so.

This is well demonstrated in the States' administration of softwood plantation development. Based on assessments of future demand, recent studies have recommended plantation establishment rates in the region of 20,000 hectares annually as being adequate. However, actual establishment rates in some years have exceeded 37,000 hectares-almost double the recommended rate. Such plantings will result in increasing surpluses of forest products, when already sizable surpluses of softwood pulpwood are beginning to emerge. Evidence available to the Committee suggests there will be very limited opportunities for the profitable disposal of this material, either on the domestic or export markets, with the end result that plantation development will be more costly than is necessary to achieve self-sufficiency, and returns will be less than adequate.

In our investigations we devoted particular attention to the vexed question of timber royalties. We found that the present methods used by the State forest services to determine royalties are the result of a patchwork of historical precedent, arbitrary valuations and impulsive responses to political pressures. In most cases, royalty levels bear no relationship to the true costs of growing wood. For instance, we found that the margin between royalties applying to rare rainforest species and to more common timber species fail to recognise the much higher inherent value of the rainforest timbers. The absence of a greater margin encourages the use of rainforest timber in applications where more common timbers would suffice. The methods of royalty determination need to be thoroughly overhauled. We hope this will be done on an Australia-wide basis. This report recommends that royalties should be directly related to the State forest services' costs of managing the plantation forests and should also recognise the scarcity value of the rare native species.

In a related aspect of forest management, the Committee found the accounts published annually by the forest services to be quite inadequate. They do not distinguish between the costs of growing wood and costs relating to other functions, such as tourism, welfare, fire control, et cetera, which the services perform. Thus it has not been possible for us to compare the relative costs and efficiency of public and private forest management. The Committee is satisfied, however, that insufficient recognition has been given to the role of private forest development, and accordingly we have recommended that decisions about future public funding of plantation development should recognise the advantages of the integration of forestry with wood processing by providing processing companies with financial incentives to establish and operate plantations.

Traditionally, the wood processing industries have depended largely upon the native hardwood forests for their raw material. In future, however, the industries will depend increasingly upon softwood plantations for their raw material base. As softwood processing lends itself to the establishment of large integrated processing plants, many of the existing small hardwood mills have a limited future. Together with technological advances and changing cost structures, the forest products industries, and particularly the sawmilling industry, face a further period of considerable structural adjustment. The Committee has recognised that this adjustment process has serious implications for many small rural communities which depend upon hardwood sawmilling as a major source of employment. However, we are of the opinion that restructuring of the industry is essential, and inevitable, if it is to compete successfully against non-wood products and imports. It is evident that this restructuring is presently occurring. We also believe that if the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission regarding the level of tariffs on the import of panelboards and mouldings were to be accepted at this stage then a number of additional firms in those industries would be forced unnecessarily into insolvency. We have recommended that any decision to reduce tariffs on these products should be deferred for five years to allow these industries to operate efficiently and profitably during the restructuring process.

The final section of the report deals with specific Commonwealth responsibilities in the area of forestry and forest products. Among other things, the Committee found that there are certain anomalies in the Income Tax Assessment Act which actually discourage the proper management of forests on privately-owned land. It would appear that while the Commonwealth has invested considerable sums in the development of plantations, the tax Act penalises landholders who manage their forests to provide timber on a continuing basis. Yet, if the landholder completely clears the forests from the land, no such tax penalty is incurred. The Committee has recommended that this and similar anomalies-such as that applying to depreciation of forestry equipment-should be removed.

I remind the Senate that 1982 is to be the International Year of the Tree. I think I speak for the entire Committee when I say that it would be our earnest hope that the world's attention should be focused on the total value of the forests, that is, their value for wood production, water catchment, recreation, scientific study and education, as a wildlife habitat, the production of honey and essential oils, for their aesthetic values, and the list goes on. Australia can be proud of its recent achievements in forestry. Within the next 20 years we will be self-sufficient in timber products, and this from a perpetually renewable resource. Yet at the same time massive areas of the forests will be excluded from timber production in recognition of the many other values of the forest estate.

Finally, I pay tribute to the former Chairman of the Committee, Glen Sheil, and to the members of the staff. Especially I must record the tremendous contribution of our Secretary, Robert Alison, whose maturity, dedication and ability were of invaluable assistance throughout the entire project. It has not been an easy task. We have assessed masses of information and to the best of my ability I believe the facts, as presented, to be accurate. There are areas where the findings clearly indicate that action is absolutely necessary. Other reports have made some of the same comments. It is of concern to the Committee that some of the identifiable difficulties that the industries now face can be attributed to lack of the attention that those matters should already have received. It is the hope of those associated with the production and presentation of this report that our findings may benefit everyone involved in the many aspects of the forestry and forest products industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Resources I want to add my words to the Chairman's report on the Committee's inquiry into the forestry and forest products industries. I believe it was unfortunate that at a vital stage of the Committee's work two of the original members of the Committee were discharged. This made the work of the two senators who replaced them even more difficult because the new members then had to catch up on what the Committee had already found out since the beginning of the inquiry and to try to make themselves conversant with the matters that were before them.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two recommendations that I particularly want to draw to the attention of the Senate. One is recommendation 54 in which the Committee recommends that each State forestry service publishes, at regular intervals, a forest management plan. It recommends that the plan should be formulated with the benefit of full public comments on its intentions; that it should describe the detailed management regime to be adopted for each and every area of forest under the service's control; that it should be explicit in its requirements so that those responsible for its implementation are in no doubt as to their responsibilities; and that it be binding for a specific period. Perhaps we could hope that implicit in that recommendation would be the ability of the State forest services to recognise that where public comment and opinions are such that it is considered environmentally or otherwise damaging for such a project to go ahead they would forgo a specific project. The other area of importance is that related to rain forests. In recommendations 57 and 58 the Committee has recommended that specific minimum standards apply to these valuable areas. One would hope once again that State forest services will implement those minimum standards, recognise that we have a valuable area to protect and do their utmost to ensure that these areas will remain for future generations. Two areas of major concern, I believe, to the Committee were the number of reports, which the Chairman of the Committee has already mentioned, which have already applied to the forestry industry-one could almost describe it as a glut situation-and the number of advisory bodies which provide information and advice to the Commonwealth Government. The recommendation in paragraph 97 calls on both the industry and interest groups to rationalise this area of advisory bodies. We recognise that it is difficult where there is a State operation, a Commonwealth government operation plus public interest operations, and we hope we will not see a plethora of these associations or organisations all offering advice and sometimes offering the same advice to the same types of committees that are being set up to investigate the industries. But I think it is important that the industry and those interest groups get together and rationalise the situation.

The Committee also looked at the application of both tariffs and taxation to the industry and recognised the problems that exist, particularly the taxation problems. We have recommended that the Government initiate within six months an examination of all aspects of taxation as they apply to the industry. The Senate, as you, Mr Deputy President, will be aware, has seen occasions when the Government has been dilatory in responding to committee reports. I hope that this report will not be one of those occasions.

The only other matter I wish to raise is the one that was brought to the Committee's attention by the Australian Council of Furniture Manufacturers which related particularly to the availability of hardwood for furniture manufacture. Let me just make the point that with all the advice and information we have had and still have available to us there is no way we can truly estimate the irreparable damage that has already been done and is perhaps still being done to our hardwood forests particularly with such diseases as dieback which has hit the Western Australian jarrah forests so badly and now I understand is attacking the tuart forests in the south-west of the State. I think it is imperative that the Government should now look at what is happening and establish whether in fact it wants to leave hardwood forests for future generations. I do not believe that we can ask industry to establish trial plantations, but evidence was given by the Australian Council of Furniture Manufacturers that at the moment the majority of hardwood that is being used for our furniture and buildings such as the Canadian redwood, is being imported. Of course, this timber attracts a tariff and makes it extremely expensive for the ultimate consumer. As there would be no return-I think the shortest time in which a hardwood industry could be established would be a period of some 20 years; the best possible average growth would be achieved somewhere between 50 and 70 years-I do not believe we should expect industry to undertake such initiatives as investigating whether we have the capacity to grow these plantations or whether they are a viable concern.

Being a parochial Western Australian, I make the point that we in that State have a large area in which large tracts of land are available-I refer to the Ord River area-with ample supplies of water easily accessible to them. There are, of course, a wide variety of hardwoods which could be the subject of some research. I am thinking of woods such as teak, ebony, cedar, jarrah, karri, wandoo, marri and tuart which at this moment do not appear to be attracting very much interest by way of research. Such an initiative would provide not only vast areas of viable forests but also large areas with tourist and recreational potential. The Chairman has already expressed the concern of the Committee that many of the existing small hardwood mills have a limited future. Perhaps this is one way in which the Government could undertake its activities during 1982, the Year of the Tree. The Chairman has touched on his concern that many valuable and well-founded recommendations of the previous inquiries have not been taken up. I sincerely hope that this matter will receive a fairly prompt response by the Government and that the recommendations that have been so carefully undertaken and the conclusions that the Committee has come to will be acceptable to the Government and will be put into operation at the earliest possible opportunity.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Joint Committee on Foreign Afairs and Defence

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I present a report on the Committee's reference on threats to Australia's security, their nature and probability, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The purpose of this report is to canvass the concept of 'threat' within the Australian context. The report is intended as a forerunner to further reports covering particular aspects of the terms of reference given to the Sub-committee on Defence Matters on 26 February 1980, which are 'to monitor the implementation of the Australian Government's announced defence programs'. The report also seeks to provide a framework for public discussion of the subsequent issues. It is the Committee's view that no analysis of the defence program can proceed without thorough understanding of the types of threats and contingencies which may be faced by the Australian defence forces. It is the Committee's hope that a frank discussion of such matters will dispel unnecessary fears, lead to an informed appreciation of Australia's regional relationships, and improve the climate of understanding between Australia and its neighbours. Moreover, it is hoped that this report brings into the public arena a more sophisticated and mature debate on Australia's security.

The report has considered threats to Australia under four headings: Firstly, potential for global conflict and its implications for Australia; secondly, invasion of Australia; thirdly, intermediate level threats to Australia's interests; and, fourthly, low level contingencies. With regard to each category of threat, the report discusses the level of capability needed to pose the type of threat, which nation might have the motive, the likely warning time involved, possible deterrents and matters that require further study. While the report devotes substantial space to the issues concerning global conflict because of the importance of this subject, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the importance for defence planning of the issues canvassed in chapters 3 and 4. These deal with intermediate level threats and low level contingencies which might require an Australian response independent of the actions of our allies, and have serious implications for the structure and capacity of our defence forces.

The Committee concluded that Australia would be a difficult invasion target. Australia is separated by oceanic distances from other countries. It has, even now, a considerable capacity to deter potential aggressors and its alliance with the United States of America involves the threat of retaliation against a major aggressor. In the world today, only a power with the immense military and economic resources of the United States would have the physical capacity to launch a full scale invasion of Australia, which is to say that Australia at present need not fear a mass invasion from any country.

With regard to the Soviet Union, even if it were in a position to contemplate an invasion of Australia, it currently lacks the appropriate equipment in the form of large attack aircraft carriers and large scale amphibious forces. The Soviet Union would also require South East Asian staging bases, which it currently does not have, to mount an invasion of Australia. It is difficult to envisage any conditions outside general world war which would lead the Soviet Union to contemplate an invasion of Australia. The Committee believes that an assault on Australia would involve a very difficult military operation, as chapter 2 of the report explains in detail. Even for an economically advanced regional power it could be expected to take at least five years to develop a capability. Other regional powers would require at least 10 years. Nevertheless, the Australian Defence Force needs to continue to sustain a technological level relevant to those of regional powers to include those long lead time capabilities which act as a deterrent to hostile action. Australia also needs to maintain the skills relevant to operations in the region and to have the capability for timely expansion of its forces.

Although the Committee believes that there is no discernible threat of invasion of Australia on which force structure can be based, there is a danger that the emergence of such a threat may take less time than is likely to be required to obtain long lead items of important equipment and increased trained manpower. There is, therefore, a heavy responsibility on our intelligence agencies and on those responsible for planning for a smooth expansion of Australia's Defence Force. A nation that spends relatively little of its gross national product on defence requires a relatively large and competent intelligence effort to keep Australia informed of developments in our region that could emerge as a threat to Australia.

In this regard, the Sub-committee on Defence Matters received significant evidence on the need to have appropriately trained intelligence analysts. In the south-west Pacific, for example, the political transition of small states has been peaceful and smooth, with the exception of Vanuatu. However, the situation in New Caledonia is also of concern to the Committee. Here there is growing movement for independence among the indigenous Melanesian population. The Committee is hopeful that following the election of the Government of Francois Mitterrand a peaceful solution can be found to the grievances of these groups. Particularly encouraging was the visit by the Secretary of State for Overseas Departments and Territories, Mr Emmanuelli, to New Caledonia, where he spoke of the need to re-examine French attitudes towards the Melanesian development which included economic and culture aspects.

The report also discusses elements current in the world situation that contribute to an uncertain global strategic outlook. A potential threat to Australia's security at present lies in a global context, rather than in our own regional situation-in the possibility of world-wide conflict or disruption of the strategic balance between super-powers. The deterioration in the global relationship between the super-powers, or possible conflicts in our region-which might attract the support of one or both of the super-powers-could affect adversely Australia's strategic prospects. It is difficult to envisage a serious strategic threat to Australia which would be unrelated to a major breakdown of the existing world order. Regrettably, the Committee believes that there is likely to be continuing and perhaps increased tension and competition between the super-powers, particularly in regions where there is instability or confrontation. Yet, on all rational calculations, nuclear war between the super-powers should be regarded as an unlikely eventuality because of the immense devastation which would result from such a conflict which would wipe out any conceivable benefits to the warring states.

In a nuclear war between the northern hemisphere powers, even if Australia were not directly targeted, we would be disastrously affected. One of the consequences of such a war would be a complete breakdown in international trade, which would have catastrophic consequences for Australia's economy. Even if Australia were not seriously affected directly by radioactive fallout from the northern hemisphere, there would be ecological consequences for the whole world which would also affect Australia.

The report discusses the joint Australian-United States facilities at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape. It points out that there is a possibility that these installations could become targets in a nuclear war. It also points out that attacks on these installations would not affect major population centres. The presence of these installations may be justified in terms of their contribution to the central balance between the super-powers. It could also be seen to confer additional advantages on Australia in its alliance with the United States. On this issue, as in the case of other threats, the Committee flags the parameters of issues that should be addressed in public debate.

I believe that the risks associated with nuclear attack on Australia have to be weighed against the value of those installations in ensuring a stable central balance, the verification of arms control agreements between the super-powers and the alliance's deterrent value against hostile actions against Australia which are beyond our capacity to resist. Our role as host obliges us to argue strongly in international forums for effective arms control agreements. Australia is more likely to suffer from low level contingency-type threats than from the threat of outright invasion or from what the Committee has called intermediate level threats. Low level threats could arise at short notice and pose challenging problems. If such a situation were to arise Australia would almost certainly be required to meet such threats from its own resources, with little or no allied support. This calls for continuing emphasis on self-reliance and on the possession of well-balanced defence forces.

Irrespective of whether significant threats to Australia develop, the Defence Force must be capable of undertaking current tasks. They include contributing to coastal and maritime surveillance. In the course of its inquiries, the Sub-committee on Defence Matters devoted considerable time and attention to this question. Evidence was taken in many parts of northern and western Australia. Support for the law enforcement agencies against terrorism is an important current task for the Defence Force. The Australian Defence Force should also have the capability to contribute to United Nations and other international peacekeeping forces.

The report stresses that the relative absence of short and medium term threats arises not only from Australia's fortunate geographical location, but also from the success, so far, of the war prevention strategy of the Western alliance, and from the comparative strength of Australia's own defence forces within our own region. Indeed, the primary aim of a defence strategy is to prevent war and not to fight it. Reassurance as to Australia's security is available only so long as the perilous balance between the super-powers is maintained or their armaments are dismantled and also so long as we continue to play our part in contributing to the Western alliance and in improving our self-reliance within the region.

On behalf of all the members of the Sub-committee and the Joint Committee, I wish to thank Mr Claus Ducker, Mr Robert King and all the staff who worked under great difficulties to finalise this report and whose enthusiasm and dedication was essential to producing it. I commend the Committee's report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although this report has had a great deal of public attention in the last few days, I believe the opportunity should not be missed to discuss some further very important implications of it. I will do that briefly at this stage. The aspects of the report that have rightly received major attention in the media and the public are those concerning the risks to Australia of nuclear attack directed at the United States bases at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape. I am not at this stage proposing to open up the immense subject of the presence of the bases in Australia, which is not really relevant to this matter. What concerns me are the likely consequences of a nuclear attack, now that there has been a clear statement that we are at risk in that direction. I would also like to know what the Government is prepared to do about it in rather more detail than we have had from the Government in the past. I will add a word or two on that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: On a number of occasions over the last two years in the Senate I have raised the need for specific civil defence mechanisms in Australia which have a relationship to our peculiar geographic need. I have especially drawn attention to the fact that Australia's position in the event of nuclear war would be very different to that of more closely settled regions, particularly the nations of Europe. The basic point that our cities are widely dispersed and sprawl over huge areas for their population size means that the likeliest form of nuclear attack, which would be single missiles presumably launched from submarines, would destroy with great certainty several square miles of the city centres and kill everybody within but leave the areas in which most of the population live subject mainly to the risk of their inhabitants suffering radiation sickness due to fallout. This would vary with individual places depending on wind speed and wind direction at the time. I was interested to note that in Friday's Australian there was an article on a report prepared by the Director of Defence Studies at the Western Australian Institute of Technology, Dr Geoffrey Williams, a former consultant to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation.
The article reads:
Australia lags markedly behind most other Western nations in its civil-defence preparedness.
He says it is essential for the nation to overcome the 'Myth' that nuclear war would mean the end of the world.
Dr Williams uses Perth as an example of what would happen to an Australian city hit by a nuclear bomb.

'Even if we take the worst case nuclear scenario for Perth, a one-megatonne ground burst with 50 per cent fission component delivered on the Perth Concert Hall at midday on a working day, the survivors would still exceed the dead and injured by a considerable margin,' . . . 'The immediate death toll out of a population of 902,000 would be 57,999, with 122,750 injured and over 154,693 temporarily affected by radioactive fallout.
'Yet 576,378 would survive.
I will repeat those figures: More than half a million people would survive opposed to an immediate death toll of 57,000 people.
The article continues:
'It is clear that with rudimentary civil-defence measures, those killed and injured could be drastically reduced by perhaps as much as 80 per cent.'
Dr Williams says Australia must include civil defence as part of a single defence posture because it is now a major factor in nuclear deterrents.

I have made the point in this place several times that a nation which is known to be unprepared offers itself as and begs to be a target because it is a place where the utmost destruction and damage can be inflicted. The country sort of chooses itself in that way. At this point I mention that I take strong exception to the very odd answer that Senator Durack gave earlier in answer to a question from Senator Kilgariff on the Government's likely response to nuclear attack. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said the civil disaster organisations-by which he meant, I take it, organisations which deal with bushfires, floods and the like-would be able to handle a nuclear attack because the circumstances would be similar. With respect to the Attorney-I know his answer was written by some public servant somewhere-that is complete and dangerous rubbish. Nuclear attack would require very different responses, and highly specialised ones. It would require rapid mass evacuation from the suburbs of large cities and complete mechanisms on computer able to carry that out quickly. It would require the decontamination of individuals and property on a huge scale. It would require major and specialised medical measures such as the availability of blood for transfusion in enormous amounts to persons affected with radiation sickness. That is the front line of defence for those people. They must be decontaminated and their symptoms can be overcome only by giving them blood transfusions.

As it happens I have not been in consultation with Dr Williams but honourable senators who care to check Hansard or who have heard me speak on the subject before will see that his comments are in very fair agreement with my own and, indeed, in complete disagreement with the Government's view which has been expressed many times. It says that we must throw our hands up and that if there is a nuclear war we can do nothing because we are all doomed anyway. Of course, this is what Dr Williams meant by referring to the myth when he said:
It is essential for the nation to overcome the 'myth' that nuclear war would mean the end of the world.

Other countries do not take this point of view. Many other countries such as Sweden, Denmark, Russia and Switzerland have hard-headed governments which have taken the view that it is very much worth while spending tens, and hundreds, of millions of dollars protecting their people in the best way they can. I suggest we must do that too. Many other organisations and individuals that also agree have been in touch with me. Now it is plain that the threat to Australia is real. I plead with the Government to pay some attention now to this matter, which so closely and so basically involves the lives and welfare of millions of Australians, which could involve us all at any time and for which we must be prepared. It is no good saying that we will take steps once the attack is launched or when it is imminent. Then it is far too late to take the kinds of measures that I have suggested.

I understand that the new Parliament House building in Queensland has an efficient nuclear shelter which will house members of the Queensland Cabinet. As Ministers here will know, I am not one of those who normally give notice of questions they propose to ask in the Senate, but I hereby give notice to Senator Messner, who represents the Minister for Housing and Construction, that tomorrow or the next day-whenever I can get the call-I will ask him just what is the situation with the new and permanent Parliament House being built here. If it is going to make provisions for elaborate civil defence measures, basements and the like for the Cabinet members and other high ranking individuals in this country, I will want to know and the Australian people will want to know why the Government takes it upon itself to put itself in safety while it leaves the rest of society at risk. I give notice that I will ask that question before this session is finished.

CANNED FRUIT INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE

During the course of debate on 19 November 1981 Senators Walsh and McLaren commented on the financial difficulties facing deciduous canning fruit growers and processors. Senator McLaren referred to the particular problems of the Riverland region of South Australia. Senator Walsh implied that a Government decision in respect of assistance to the beef industry in 1977 and a current proposal to introduce an underwriting scheme for sultanas were evidence that an IAC inquiry was not a prerequisite to Government assistance to the canned fruit industry. I would like to clarify the position for honourable Senators, although I am somewhat surprised at the apparent suggestion opposite that advice should not be sought as to the form of assistance likely to be most effective in dealing with the difficulties confronting the canned fruit industry.

The terms of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 allow for financial assistance to be provided to an industry for up to a period of two years without a mandatory IACS report provided that the period or sum of the periods of any previous financial assistance since commencment of the IAC Act has not exceeded two years duration. As such, it was possible to extend short term assistance to beef producers in 1977 through the animal husbandry incentive scheme in the absence of a prior IAC report. The canned fruit industry has received assistance through the Fruitgrowing Reconstruction Scheme which operated from 1972 to 1977 and special carry-on loans provided to canneries in 1976. These measures have precluded the provision of any further assistance without an IAC inquiry.

In relation to Senator Walsh's analogy with dried fruit underwriting, I point out, by way of clarification, that in 1977 the Government rejected a central finding of the IAC that the dried vine fruit stabilisation scheme be phased out over three years. It decided that the stabilisation scheme should be extended for the three seasons 1978 to 1980 and that at the end of the second season the scheme be reviewed with a view to determining long-term action. That review resulted in the proposal to introduce an underwriting arrangement for sultanas, the details of which were set out in the Minister's Second Reading Speech in the other place on 29 October 1981.

I trust that it is clear that there is nothing unique about the Government's decision to seek a report from the IAC before addressing the question of assistance needs of the canned fruit industry. The fact that there may be hardships for particular people or regions which warrant urgent consideration has been recognised by the Government and, accordingly, the IAC has been asked to provide an interim report by 31 March 1982 on the nature and extent of any short term assistance considered appropriate.
The Government's approach on this matter is a responsible one and is entirely consistent with its continuing emphasis on sound management of Government expenditure.

DEREGISTRATION OF STEIGER'S EST. 775
Background

During estimates hearings on 19 November 1981, Senator Primmer expressed confusion over certain aspects of the deregistration for export of the independent meat establishment located at Northcote, Victoria, and operated by Steiger's Meat Supply (Australia) Pty Ltd. This confusion arose because:
(a) Bureau of Animal Health meat inspection staff located at 775 have not found any evidence of out-of-hours activity, and
(b) a press report quoted a Director of Steigers as saying the horsemeat was found in cartons sampled in an establishment neither owned by nor under the control of Steigers.
SUGGESTED RESPONSE

The export registration of Steiger's premises at 82 Bastings Street, Northcote was cancelled on 23 September 1981 by the secretary of the Department of Primary Industry. This cancellation followed the finding of horsemeat in cartons of beef mince in a cold store at Brooklyn operated by Klari Meat Export Pty Ltd. The mince concerned was packed in sealed plastic tubes, which in turn were packed in cardboard cartons. The plastic tubes and cartons were labelled and marked to show their origin as being establishment 775, Steiger's Bastings Street premises. Accompanying documentation showed that the consignment had been transferred from establishment 775 to the cold store at which sampling took place. All the samples taken were positive for horsemeat.
It has never been suggested by the Bureau of Animal Health that horse carcases or quarters have been boned at the Bastings Street premises.
Enquiries by the Australian Federal police are proceeding.
Australian Bureau of Animal Health
23 November 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only notes on the third matter. On 19 November Senator McLaren raised a series of questions about money being recovered by the Australian Government from the sale of confiscated Taiwanese fishing vessels and whether the Government would consider tightening the fisheries laws to make the penalties much higher and deter foreign fishermen from depriving Australian fishermen of their living. I pointed out at that time that in the example given by Senator McLaren the inability of the fishermen to pay the fine meant simply that there was a larger burden on the taxpayer because of the pending imprisonment of the fishermen and that the imposition of an even higher fine would simply increase the loss to revenue. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has given me some more information on these matters. I advise the Committee that-as I am sure it will be aware-the decision whether to order the forfeiture of foreign boats involved in breaches of Australian fisheries laws rests with the courts. The Department of Primary Industry has implemented procedures to give effect to the recommendations in paragraph 2.44 of the 187th Report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts concerning the disposal of forfeited boats, to establish a criterion based on anticipated net realisable value. If the cost of a forfeited boat's disposal exceeds the anticipated sale price, it should be disposed of promptly by destruction. The sense behind that is fairly evident.

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator McLaren's information, the sale of forfeited boats back to former owners ceased at the Minister's direction in October 1976. The Department is currently examining the question of sale of forfeited catches back to former owners but that can occur only when the court has not ordered forfeiture of the boat. By leaving the catch in the boat the Commonwealth saves the cost of unloading and storing ashore. The former owner would be entitled to make a bid in competition with any interested Australian buyers. Consideration of the former owner's bid would take account of unloading and other costs. It has always been open to former owners to tender for the repurchase of forfeit boats. If their bid were satisfactory it may be successful in accordance with normal tendering practices.

The Minister for Primary Industry some time ago reviewed the penalties which Senator McLaren raised in Committee. The monetary levels are considered satisfactory. The maximum fine in summary jurisdiction is $5,000 and the maximum fine on indictment is $250,000. These are among the world's highest for the offence of unlicensed use of a fishing boat in exclusive fishing zones. In addition to that monetary penalty, the courts at their discretion may also order forfeiture of boat, catch, fishing gear and so on. The Department of Primary Industry is currently reviewing the policy with regard to forfeitures to determine whether a different basis for forfeiture is appropriate as between licensed and unlicensed foreign boats. This review is part of a more general review of the fisheries laws currently in progress. Under the agreement with Taiwanese commercial interests, the Tiawanese are to meet Commonwealth or State government costs following apprehension and conviction of licensed or unlicensed vessels. The Taiwanese have complied with this requirement.

Apart from the penalties imposed under Australian fishery laws, the Taiwanese have, under the agreement, imposed their own controls which are designed to eliminate illegal Taiwanese fishing activities in Australian waters. These controls involve the suspension or cancellation of licences, fines, and even imprisonment and have resulted in a sharp downturn in illegal activity. There is no instance in which foreign fishermen are fishing out many of the areas on which Australian fishermen depend. The recently concluded tuna long-line fishing agreement with Japan excludes that country's boats from a wider area of the Australian fishing zone than ever before so as to further reduce competition with Australian tuna vessels. The Taiwanese are the only people trawling on the North West Shelf and gillnetting in northern waters. If Australians gear up to enter either of those fisheries they will be given preference and Taiwanese activities will be reduced accordingly. The existing regulatory and enforcement measures are designed to protect the living resources of the Australian fishing zone and continental shelf consistent with the effective and economical allocation of assets to implement those measures.

In addition, Senator Walsh raised again the question of the 'dry run', as he described it, of the Department's appearance before the Estimates Committee. I repeat what I said in the Senate on 19 November: I do not see anything vaguely wrong with officers preparing themselves for what can be quite intensive and rigorous questioning. If one looks at the record of the questioning of the Estimates Committee this year one will find that for a number of departments senators chose to ask questions in extremely harsh terms and in great detail on a variety of subjects. I think that any prudent department would come to the Estimates Committee hearings equipped, as best possible, to deal with the questions which are to be raised.

I am sorry if in any sense I misled Senator Walsh or the Senate when I advised that there was a new Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry. Senator Walsh has drawn my attention to the fact that the Secretary took office in the first half of 1980. I agree that the inference from what I said would be that he was perhaps newer than that and hence had not had experience of Estimates committees with respect to this Department. My advice is that the Secretary to the Department had not previously attended the Senate Estimates committees in 1980 or for the Additional Estimates in 1981. The point I made was in that context and on the basis of advice that he was new. It now appears that he was new in the sense that I have just outlined.

In any event, it is possible to see a problem, a conspiracy, something wrong in almost any act if one is so minded. It is not unusual for there to be preparation for Question Time, in the case of some Ministers. It is not unusual, I think, for departments to prepare for the Estimates committees, where they publicly appear before the Parliament to answer whatever questions are put to them by members of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not suggest that there is anything necessarily improper, as a general practice, about departments making preparation or having a dry run for Senate Estimates committee hearings. I simply note that it had never happened before in the Department of Primary Industry. I do not believe that it is coincidental that it happened at this time. The Department and its present and previous Ministers were under the hammer because of scandals which had previously been disclosed. In short, this was a department with something to hide. It still is a department with something to hide. Although the Department has escaped full exposure so far that may not last forever. One would have to be incredibly naive to believe that it was entirely coincidental that the dry run was conducted in this Department at this time.

—Merely because the people concerned are in no position to defend themselves I point out that it seems to me to be a matter of simple logic and common sense that, in a situation where there is considerable public interest and where there has been an attack on certain aspects of the administration of the Department-as clearly there has been in the Parliament over recent months-there is a simple rule or prudence that there should be the most careful preparation for an appearance before an Estimates committee. —The matter I want to take up concerns breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and misleading information given by the Department of Trade and Resources to Estimates Committee H on 12 October. But it is a fact that in March of this year arrangements were made under which, in exchange for a purchase of an Australian commodity, rebates on import duty were granted to particular firms. The commodity purchased by the firms that were granted the rebate on import duty was subsequently exported which, by any reasonable definition of course, is an export subsidy. That was introduced in March of this year, and those facts are not in dispute. I asked a First Assistant Secretary of the Department, Mr Webb, whether our trading partners had been formally notified of the operation of the scheme, and in reply he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no obligation to notify them formally, to the best of my recollection.

As far as the response from the Department of Trade is concerned, that remains the case. The Department of Trade sticks by that answer. I shall quote article XVI of GATT, the first paragraph of which states:
If any contracting party grants or maintains any subsidy, including any form of income or price support, which operates directly or indirectly-
This is the critical line-

to increase exports of any product from, or to reduce imports of any products into, its territory, it shall notify the Contracting Parties in writing of the extent and nature of the subsidization . . .

An inducement was offered to a number of firms to buy an Australian product. The inducement was a remission of duty which would otherwise be payable on their imports. The product was subsequently exported. Those facts are not in dispute. A First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Trade said there was no obligation to notify other signatories to GATT, formally or informally, to the best of his recollection, of those arrangements. The Department of Trade still stands by that answer. I repeat what is stated in Article XVI:
. . . any form of income or price support, which operates directly or indirectly to increase exports of any product from . . . it-
That is the contracting country; in this case, Australia-
shall notify the Contracting Parties in writing of the extent and nature of that subsidization . . .

That presumably was not done. That is one thing; to have attempted to mislead the Committtee in the way the Committee was misled is another and, from the point of view of this Parliament, an even more serious case. Certainly that product would not have been exported from Australia had the arrangements which were concluded in March not been made. This whole exercise was organised by Mr Anthony, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources, the fellow who pre-empts all Cabinet decisions on any subject on which he chooses to pre-empt Cabinet decisions. Most recently, he has been running around the country pre-empting Cabinet decisions on the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. Our trading partners were not notified of this arrangement, under which an indirect subsidy was paid to increase the export of an Australian product, in clear breach of Article XVI of GATT. The offence was then compounded by misleading advice given to the Senate by First Assistant Secretary Webb. He was obviously very uneasy while he was giving the advice.

There is a secondary matter on the same subject in which the Department came clean. I asked whether any complaint had been received from any of our trading partners about this arrangement. As recorded at page 657 of the Hansard Estimates report of 12 October, I asked:

Mr Webb replied:
Off the top of my head I cannot remember. I cannot answer that categorically.

I went on to ask whether the information would be available and whether it would be supplied and the answer was yes. That information subsequently was supplied. A letter dated 14 October received by the Committee from the Department of Trade and Resources stated:

The Department advises that representations were received from the United States after announcement of the concession . . . In response, Australia advised the United States that its assertions were formulated with insufficient detail to permit a specific response.

On that issue one could say that certainly the relevant First Assistant Secretary should have known of such a complaint. However, further accurate information was supplied to the Committee subsequently within a reasonable time. That is not the case with the arrangement itself and our clear obligations under Article XVI of GATT and the equally clear obligation of officers to tell the truth to Senate Estimates commitees. If they find that they made a mistake at the time the Senate Estimates committee was sitting, it is the obligation not of the department, but of the Minister, to see that the truth is told to the committee. In this case that clearly was not done.

The Minister then intervened. He said he found the question quite inappropriate. It is inappropriate if one is trying to protect the Minister for Trade and Resources but it is not an inappropriate question for this Parliament to ask.

I invite the Minister to comment on the misleading answer given, and not subsequently corrected regarding our obligations under Article XVI of the GATT. Secondly, I invite him again to obtain statutory declarations from all the First Assistant Secretaries of the Department of Trade and Resources to the effect that they have no knowledge of what I have called at various times the bureaucratic harassment or blackmailing of the firm concerned.

Dear Senator Baume,

Following consideration of the Department of Trade and Resources' estimates for 1981/82, you referred to me for advice, a question arising from a report by the Australian Broadcasting Commission concerning an address made by the Senior Trade Commissioner, Jakarta to a group of businessmen in Darwin (Hansard: 12 October, 1981, Estimates Committee H, p. 662).

It is standard practice that Trade Commissioners, while on briefing programmes in Australia, meet with Australian businessmen to inform them of the market conditions and normal commercial practices in our trading partner countries.

During a recent visit to Australia, the Senior Trade Commissioner, Jakarta, spoke to a group of Australian businessmen in Darwin for this purpose. He spoke from notes and, as is usual in these circumstances, no transcript of his address was taken. I am informed that, during the course of his address, the Senior Trade Commissioner quoted from two pieces of publicly available material relating to Indonesia, the first a speech given by an Indonesian at a Stanford Research Institute Meeting in September 1974 and the second, a feature article in the Melbourne 'Age' issue of 25 April, 1981 which reported comments attributed to an Indonesian.
Quotation One

''Conflicts in words and conflicts in feeling should be avoided even at great personal and psychological cost. In conversations and negotiations with others all parties should try to emphasise the items everybody agrees with, whereas conflicting matters should not be discussed for fear of hurting the feelings of others. This type of relationship makes it almost inevitable that a clear and outright 'no' as an answer to some suggestion is taken as crude and unrefined behaviour. If one wants to say 'no' the polite way to do it is to say 'yes, but . . . . '

What comes after the word 'but' really carries the negative message. More difficult to catch is the Javanese 'no' formulated in the word 'yes', but denied by facial expression or behavioural rejection.
In essence, the Javanese . . . . 'yes' in most cases means 'I do understand you', and is far from 'I agree with you' and even farther from 'I promise to do what you want me to do'.

Recognising the subtle feelings of the Indonesian and particularly those of the Javanese, it is advisable never to make him ashamed in the presence of others. In fact the feeling of shame is a function of degrading of respectability in the eyes of other people. There is never a feeling of shame with an individual who is entirely alone with no other human being to watch or hear him''. End quote
The Senior Trade Commissioner went on to say

''At the other end of the spectrum, referring to 'necessary' behaviour patterns required to do business, and even survive in Indonesia, one can refer to an article that appeared in the ''Age'' on 25 April, 1981''.
Quotation Two

''Everyone has to bend to corruption, it's the system. You play it by ear as to when to pay, how much and when to refuse. Sure you can take a great moral stand against it-and lose your credit rating, your job, your liberty and even your life''. End quote

I would draw your attention to the fact that the Senior Trade Commissioner was quoting from a newspaper article. He offered no comment on, or elaboration of, the article and, thus, cannot be said to have advocated or condoned the practices referred to in that newspaper article.
I am advised that the Senior Trade Commissioner made no reference to bribery or corruption in his responses to questions following his address in Darwin.

As a consequence of the inaccurate and misleading report by the Australian Broadcasting Commission of his address in Darwin the Senior Trade Commissioner deleted the second quotation from his subsequent talks in Australian capital cities.

It is for businessmen to make their own judgements as to the approach most likely to achieve their commercial objectives. This is not an area in which they are, or should be, susceptible to influence by Trade Commissioners or officials. Trade Commissioners and officials would be failing in their duty if they were to withhold information that could be crucial to businessmen in making their commercial judgements.

Having said this, I should stress that it is not Government policy to encourage firms to engage in activities overseas that would be in breach of the laws of the countries with which they are trading. Should the Committee wish, I am prepared to make available to members of the Committee the full text of the speech notes used by the Senior Trade Commissioner when addressing the group of businessmen in Darwin.

Thirdly, the customary practice is that any contracting party which believes its interests are being harmed by specific measures which it-that is the aggrieved contracting party-judges to be inconsistent with the GATT may take the matter up at the regular monthly GATT meeting held in Geneva to discuss such matters.
