TALK.START.PARA: —The debate we are now beginning is really a continuation of a previous debate in this place. The legislation before us is the result of the Government's response to decisions previously taken in this place. The Government has set aside the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981, which was amended by the Senate, and has introduced two new Bills-the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 (No. 2) and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. The first Bill provides for federal assistance to tertiary education and is similar to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981. However, provisions for the charging of fees have been removed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, of course, has no objection to the provision of federal assistance to tertiary institutions contained in this Bill. In fact, as the Opposition has made clear on many occasions in this place, it would like to see increased Federal Government expenditure on tertiary education. We are only too well aware of the difficulties that tertiary institutions are labouring under throughout this country. Of course, we are not opposing the Bill insofar as it provides funds for tertiary institutions. Indeed, it is our wish to see those funds increased. However, the other issue raised by this Bill is the amalgamation of tertiary institutions. In the view of the Opposition the current proposals for amalgamation of certain tertiary institutions cannot be supported. They are poorly thought out. They seem to have been motivated by the desire to save public funds rather than by the desire to improve education. Like many of the recommendations of the Lynch committee, of which this is just one, they will not achieve any greater efficiency or rationalisation of the resources they are attempting to rationalise. In fact, they will create a lot more confusion and we believe they will harm the quality and diversity of tertiary education in this country.

In particular, we are very concerned about the amalgamation proposal for the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education. When I say 'in particular', we are concerned about other amalgamations but the particular amalgamation in Townsville is one which is not defensible in terms of efficiency or educational standards. We are very concerned about the fact that a Bill to effect this amalgamation is now before the Queensland Parliament. The Queensland Government has indicated its opposition to the amalgamation arising from the Lynch committee recommendation but under pressure has introduced the Bill providing for amalgamation.

The Bill provides that the College of Advanced Education in Townsville will be incorporated into the University as an autonomous institute, that new courses will require ministerial approval and that there will be the appointment of an advisory council consisting of five government appointees and four members of the University Council. They will, firstly, implement the Act; secondly, maintain standards in north Queensland; and thirdly, generally supervise advanced education in north Queensland. It will not come as any surprise to the Government to hear that we are particularly concerned at the erosion of autonomy of the newly amalgamated institution. In particular, we object to the fact that new courses to be introduced into the University of Townsville will now require ministerial approval at State level. That seems to us to be totally opposed to the principle of university autonomy and totally to cut across the concept of expertise and specialist decisions being taken by those who are properly able to take them.

Similarly, we are very concerned at the provision for State Government appointment of advisory council members. In fact, five appointees to the new council will be appointed by the State Government. Again, that provision seems to us to be totally contrary to the principle of university autonomy. I believe there is no valid argument for saying that these kinds of appointments are in the interests of the best standards of education. I understand that Senator Macklin, who of course represents the State of Queensland in this place, will want to make more detailed comments on this proposal. Therefore, I will make general points on behalf of the Australian Labor Party in regard to the amalgamation in Townsville. We recognise that the amalgamation will mean great difficulty for the University and CAE. In New South Wales, other institutions have been granted a further 12 months to finalise the amalgamation proposals. This indulgence of a period in which to re-organise circumstances should have been extended to Townsville. The Federal Government has washed its hands of the issues and the difficulties involved. The budgets for both the University and the College have gone to the University. In determining the size of the budget it has been assumed that there will be a reduction in costs and consequent savings. Under the arrangement if a college insists on carrying out its traditional function there will be no saving in cost in the college area. The saving will be made in the area of traditional university activities. It is our view that the Government has rushed this proposal through to the detriment of higher education in north Queensland, that the Government ought to be able to assure us that there will be a full range of higher education facilities in Townsville and that the Government ought to assure the Parliament that there will be no interference in the autonomy of the university.

Finally, of course, it must be said that we regard this ad hoc method of handing over tertiary institution functions to State governments as totally unacceptable. In allowing the Queensland Bill to go before the Parliament in its present form the Federal Government has abandoned its responsibility in respect of ensuring the qualitative development of higher education in north Queensland. The other general objections we have with regard to the amalgamation I think can be extrapolated from the example I have given of the problems that will arise in Townsville. In view of our objections to many of the amalgamations proposed and the way in which many of them have been pursued, I now move on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the second reading motion in respect of the Bill. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-

(1) the University/College of Advanced Education amalgamations proposed in Newcastle, Armidale, Wollongong and Townsville should not proceed until arrangements satisfactory to both parties to the amalgamation have emerged;

(2) those Colleges of Advanced Education in New South Wales and Victoria for which no satisfactory amalgamation proposal exists should be funded until proposals satisfactory to the staff and students of the colleges involved are determined, and
(3) the Government should provide guarantees backed by special financial support to ensure that where amalgamations occur the-
(A) existing range of education opportunities are maintained,
(B) employment security of staff is safeguarded, and
(C) academic integrity of the institutions is protected'.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately three Bills dealing with appropriations for tertiary education. I turn my attention to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. This Bill attempts to reintroduce the provisions for charging fees which the Senate removed from the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981. The Opposition will oppose the motion that the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 Bill be read a second time. I remind the Senate in a summary manner of the reasons for our opposition to the provisions for the imposition of fees in tertiary institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: In our view, the imposition of fees would reduce access to education. That is our fundamental objection. It is an objection that can be sustained by various surveys that have been carried out by the Australian Union of Students and other organisations. It is not in the interests of this society or in the interests of individuals in this society to have the opportunity for higher education removed. That is our fundamental objection. We also fear that it is the intention of the Government to impose fees for all tertiary students and that this provision to impose fees for second and higher degrees is merely a first step in that direction, although perhaps I should say a second step in that direction since fees for overseas students have already been imposed.

There is no economic justification for the provision, no financial argument in favour of it. The amount to be collected as a result of the imposition of fees for second and higher degrees is estimated by the Government to be $8m in a full year, a figure which in our view is an optimistic estimate. That figure will be eroded by administrative costs. The Senate should be reminded that that figure of something less than $8m, which could be gained by the imposition of fees compares in an insignificant way with the Budget appropriation for education of $1.865 billion. Therefore, there can be no argument that the collection of fees in this way would have any significant effect; it would have only the most miniscule effect on the provision of funds for education in this country.

It should also be pointed out that the money to be collected through the reintroduction of fees would not be used to assist lower or middle income people to undertake tertiary education. It is not a matter of redistribution from the wealthy, or those able to pay, to those not able to pay, as perhaps the Government would like to pretend. It will not be used, for example, to increase funding for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, which is so low as to prevent many potential students from undertaking tertiary studies. This Bill seeks simply to take money out of education and to allow the Government to redirect it elsewhere. Of course, we are very concerned that, at a time of rapid technological and economic change, the Government should be encouraging people to acquire new skills and to upgrade their qualifications. This is not happening. The contrary is happening. The Government is discouraging people from undertaking the kind of specialist studies which would enable them and enable our society and our economy to cope with structural and technological change.

It is, as I have pointed out before in this place, an anomalous circumstance that students can drop out of higher studies and get more money by way of the unemployment benefit than by way of tertiary education assistance. In other words, the financial strategies of this Government in regard to education funding are actually encouraging people to seek unemployment instead of advancing their skills and knowledge and making themselves more able to contribute to the society. By comparison with other nations, the Australian Government ranks education as a low priority and, in the view of the Opposition, it is of no benefit to the community to have vast numbers of people unskilled and undereducated, which is the situation at present. For these reasons, and the reasons which my colleagues have set forth in the previous debate on this matter, we will oppose the second reading of this Bill.

The third Bill before the Senate this evening is the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. This Bill attempts to reintroduce provisions for charging fees at the Australian National University which the Senate removed from the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. The Federal Opposition will oppose this Bill for the reasons I have just stated with respect to the previous Bill. There is a separate Bill, of course, because the Australian Government directly legislates for the Australian National University. But because we are equally concerned to see an increase in access for students to that university, we will be opposing this Bill at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak for only a few minutes on part of this legislation-the section in relation to tuition fees. I believe there is in the community quite a misconception regarding the intention of this legislation because the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have been speaking as though it is the general intention to bring in tuition fees for all students studying for second and third degrees to cover the total costs of those courses. That is why the misconception arises. I will just go over what the taxpayer pays for education in this country. The taxpayers, some of whom are on very low incomes, pay for the education of a person from five years old right through to completion of matriculation. Not only that, but in Australia we also have completely free primary degree courses. The taxpayers have also been footing the bill for someone who wants to go further to get a second degree. The taxpayers also foot the bill at the moment for higher degrees, including masters degrees and doctorates. I believe the taxpayer has had enough of this.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxpayer pays an allowance under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme to a student whose parents come within a certain means-tested bracket. If that university student wants to live a full life and get married, the taxpayer will foot that bill too. Indeed, the taxpayer will then support the wife of the university student. If he wants then to have children, the taxpayer again foots the bill. The taxpayer will support those children, no matter how many the student desires to have. At our universities there are people who become professional students and who do degree after degree. A certain number of students decide to do a primary degree, a masters degree and then a doctorate. That is fair enough, and those who indulge in research would possibly go through those three degrees. The taxpayer can be asked to pay a living allowance to the wife and children of the student who wants to do that. In 1980 an estimated 13,250 students did such courses.

The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, of which I am Chairman, has been investigating over the last few months a group of homeless young people who have been living in refuges and who, as soon as they get a job, start paying tax. They are a very disadvantaged group of children who, no matter how bright or intelligent they are, would never think of doing a university course. They must look at us in absolute wonder when we say that they, as low income tax payers, will pay not only for a university student to do a second or third degree but will also pay a living allowance for the wife and children of that university student.

These people, with the accumulation of all these degrees, can then set about earning a considerable amount of money-indeed, pay tax on that-having been given this education completely free by the taxpayers of Australia. The Government is asking that the taxpayers be relieved of about 17 per cent to 18 per cent, on average, of the cost of the second and third degrees. This is what the fuss is all about. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats make great play of justice in this country. This Opposition says that it believes that the poor of this country should have justice. There is no justice in getting these people on low incomes to pay this tremendous cost in the area of education. I believe that if it is just a principle which is attached to this Bill that university students, who will end up having a considerably higher income than any of the group-

TALK.START.PARA: —And paying higher taxes.

—Senator Georges has bitten and said that they will be paying higher taxes. That is not his usual cry. Yes, they will be paying higher taxes. When Senator Georges goes around the shelters, sees the children who are on the lower incomes and finds the sorts of jobs they are doing in the factories he will see that they certainly do not have any job satisfaction. But the university students who have second and third degrees and who are doing research will never be asked to work in the factories and just press a button all day long. They will go ahead and do jobs which give them complete and utter satisfaction. The will be paying higher taxes because they will be earning more, but they will be getting complete and utter satisfaction out of their jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: All I ask is that the Opposition thinks again and thinks of that group of people who are being forced to pay taxes for this elite group of university students who have the world before them. They will have jobs in which they will have complete satisfaction. We are asking them to pay just $2,000 over the whole time they are studying for a masters degree or $3,000 over the whole time they are studying for a Ph.D. It is estimated that only 17.7 per cent of the 13,250 students doing second and third degrees are full time students. The rest are part time students well able to pay that paltry amount. We are asking the students to pay a small amount. I believe that the Opposition and the Democrats, if there is any sincerity at all in their cry for us to help those underprivileged people, should pass these Bills in this chamber tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 14 October I spoke in this chamber in relation to education, mentioning specifically the problem of biotechnology. I raise that matter again in relation to these Bills, specifically the funding of universities and colleges of advanced education, because interestingly enough in the last week there has been a conference on that matter in Australia. I wish to refer to a report in the Weekend Australian concerning the visit to Australia of Dr Herman Lewis, Director of Human Cell Biology at the National Science Foundation of the United States of America, who came here this week for the conference and has made a number of pronouncements on the importance of biotechnology to the American economy.

SPEECH.PARA: In outlining his plan he gave four points for the development in Australia of a climate which would be conducive to the fostering of this high technology industry. The plan is aimed at attracting high risk investment in biotechnology-we all admit that it is a necessity-and encouraging company research. One of the main planks of his plan was to boost linkages between universities in which the most valuable genetic engineering studies are currently taking place. The point I was making on 14 October, a month ago, was precisely that-that our universities have been in the forefront of world development in this area, yet we are letting slip through our fingers the opportunity to capitalise on that work by not developing a viable and productive industry in the field.

Dr Lewis is also reported to have said that in the last six months in America over 100 new companies had been formed and over $1,000m had developed in those industries annually; that the vast importance of those industries to the American economy, not only now but also in the future, was such that the type of expenditure needed to go on. In Australia we have few opportunities to look towards such high risk capital and company investment in research, but to date we have been in the forefront of world advances in this industry.

However, we have not been able to capitalise on those advances. Indeed we are now setting about destroying that base by the way in which we seek to fund university research and development. Indeed, that point was a fundmental reason given by the Australian Democrats for our opposition to the imposition of fees. It had nothing to do with the moral qualities or otherwise of students paying or not paying for their higher degrees, or whether some students would go on to do higher degrees when they ought to be doing something else. We were looking at the much broader and far-reaching implications of destroying our research base when we needed it most. Contrary to what Senator Walters has said, when we took that particular stance, we were concerned about the underprivileged and the poor. We believe, and I thought until Senator Walters spoke that the Government also believed, that the development of a healthy economy provides the best basis for the support and succour of those who are in distress, and the provision of genuine and useful programs for those who are disadvantaged.

We believe that, whilst there has been an increase in funding under the States Grants Bills, which we applaud, it has not been sufficient. It certainly has not been sufficient to meet the types of demands that the universities have made upon them and the types of things that, given their infrastructure and capital development to date, they are capable of achieving. By making use of the vast base that we have developed in Australia our universities could indeed contribute much more to our economy. This is what we should seek to do as rapidly as possible and with as much foresight as we can manage. To date we have not been noted for looking much beyond the next election.

The Williams Report on Education, training and employment, which was handed down and which, unfortunately, did not receive the type of attention it ought to have, pointed out a very interesting fact, namely, that the highest proportions of graduate students are in agriculture, engineering, education and the natural sciences. Post-graduate research in agriculture, engineering and science in particular, is exacting and make heavy demands on the students concerned. If fees are added to the existing commitment as is proposed under the amendments, both to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act and to the Australian National University Act, the deterrent effect could be considerable, especially as the problems of inflation and unemployment have already made post-graduate study in this country far less attractive than it has been, even in the last couple of years.

I have already stated and the Australian Democrats have pointed out time and again that the prosperity of Australia for the remainder of this century is closely linked to the welfare of primary industry and the development of our natural resources but, more importantly, to the ability of industry to adjust to rapid technological change. In those circumstances, we believe that to discourage graduates seeking advanced expertise in relevant areas is remarkably ill-considered and certainly runs against the whole tenor of responsible economic management. Therefore, we do not support, on that basis alone, the proposition of the imposition of fees. We remain neutral as to whether that will assist the moral advancement or otherwise of students. But we do not consider that to be a relevant point when one is looking at the overall economic development of this country into the next century.

These Bills have now been brought forward in a new form. The Australian Democrats find it regrettable that this chamber has not yet seen fit to debate its powers in relation to these Bills as has the House of Representatives. Unfortunately, we have not yet had a statement from the President of the Senate on this matter although the Speaker of the House of Representatives has made a couple of statements in relation to the power of that chamber. We hope that at some time in the near future this chamber may be able to discuss this issue and make its point of view clearly known. But, we do, in fact, applaud the Government for bringing forward these Bills at last in the correct form. The 1967 compact very clearly made the point that new policies, when brought forward, ought not be included in money Bills but ought to be brought forward in separate legislation and discussed purely on their merits. We applaud the Government for at last undertaking to do that and for having brought these Bills forward in this correct fashion as they ought to have been presented in the first place.

It is a pity that we had the original debate on the Bill in that form which did not enable us to tease it out. I am sure that Senator Ryan would have welcomed the opportunity to have had a much more in depth and discursive discussion in relation to States grants and the whole issue of university funding whereas previously we had to concentrate on the new policy area and look at that. We hope that in the future, certainly in the next session of this Parliament, the Government will bring forward Bills, drafted in that way, in agreement with the compact of 1967 so that we are able to discuss the new policy developments of this Government on their merits and not have this type of situation arising again.

The Australian Democrats will support the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill (No. 2) and also the Australian Labor Party's amendment. We will oppose the Bill to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act and the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 in relation to tuition fees. The other Bill which was originally part of this package and which related to the Canberra College of Advanced Education of course, was concerned solely with fees. It has already been rejected by this Senate and doubtless has enabled the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to start counting the months to when he can pull the trigger. We believe that it is not a relevant issue in relation to this. Unfortunately, the whole discussion about a double dissolution or whatever has tended to cloud what we believe is an extremely important and relevant issue, not only now in Australia, but also in the future. We must come to grips with the vast technological changes that are now occurring in the world. We must provide sufficient moneys so that Australia can at least remain with, if not ahead of, other developed countries in this area. We again urge the Government to look at its priorities and see whether or not we have been underfunding our universities and college of advanced education for the next generation.

In conclusion, I point out what a very eminent Australian said in relation to this matter. Professor Passmore stated: 'There is a real prospect that we will lose not just one but two or three generations of scientists and scholars who will find it impossible to get a permanent university appointment'. The real problems facing a steady State university are such that in 1990 we will find that we will be without an adequate tertiary education base to provide not only the type of research that is needed for our industry but also an education for our citizens. I believe that we must give much more urgent attention to this matter. We would have wished to debate those types of long-range principles instead of having had to deal with what seems to be purely a short term political move on the part of the Goverment, namely its decision to impose fees. We certainly hope that in the future we will be able to move to those broader matters of principle and economic planning so that this country will know that there will be sufficient people to provide for those who are retiring and those who are unemployed. Unless we have developed technological industry we certainly will not be able to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate we are dealing with the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 (No. 2), the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and the fees Bill, the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. As far as the first two Bills are concerned, the funding Bills, I make it perfectly clear-I have mentioned this to the Government-that it is very important for the Government and the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) to understand that in a small university there is a degree of diversification. The costs of such a university providing a service would, so far as economies of scale are concerned, in normal circumstances be higher than those of other universities. Of course, that applies to the University of Tasmania. I believe that there is a very substantial situation to which the Government must face up in respect of that type of university. In a State such as Tasmania, tertiary educational institutions must, of course, serve the whole of the State. There is, as has been said in this chamber on a number of occasions, a problem relating to the north-west coast of our State. I intend to take up with the Government the cause of constituents within the tertiary institutions in my State in the hope that the Government will ensure that special recognition is given to the needs of tertiary education in the State of Tasmania. Whilst there has been an increase in the amount of funding for educational institutions it is perfectly clear, not only in my State but also right throughout Australia, that the academic community is extremely worried that the quality of education could be affected as a result of the level of funding. I have heard it said, quite openly, that quotas will need to be applied in certain faculties, and maybe they already apply in certain faculties.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to the fees issue. One of the concerns I have is related to quotas. If permanent students who are taking up places in facilities are doing their third, fourth or fifth degrees, or whatever, we must surely give to the institutions the right to make some sort of decision as to the contributions those persons should make towards their degrees. Senator Mason on behalf of the Australian Democrats has indicated that their oposition to fees is based on the fact that a determination made by the Minister requiring institutions to impose fees in fact could be directed and could strike at the heart of the research base in Australia. I agree with that. I do not think it is necessary for me to canvass all the points that were canvassed two weeks ago when this legislation last came before the Senate. Suffice it to say that some higher degree students-we are talking about higher degree students here-who are on scholarships are living in penury as a result of inadequate scholarships which have not been indexed. Sufficient evidence has been provided to me to convince me that the imposition of fees on higher degree students could have a substantially deleterous effect on the amount of research work, work of excellence, being undertaken in universities, which, as has been said, ultimately benefits the whole of the community.

The same sort of case cannot be mounted in respect of the imposition of fees for non-meal-ticket second, third and fourth degrees. I deliberately use the phrase 'non-meal-ticket second, third and fourth degrees' because some people need a second degree for a meal ticket. When certain employers and certain areas of expertise require maybe two degrees, then it is a question of meal ticket. Nevertheless, as to the other degrees, the same argument cannot be mounted as can be mounted to protect those students who are attempting to achieve higher degrees and are involved in the research that has been referred to.

Let us not have any illusions about where the Senate is heading on this matter. As has been said, the Government is moving towards a situation in which it can have the loaded section 57 constitutional gun in the locker. I am not at all fussed about that. I am not fussed about the implied threats that are being thrown around from time to time in the Press by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), but by the same token I consider it is the duty of the Senate to exercise its scrutiny powers in a manner which is palatable all round, if that is possible.

That is the reason I moved the amendment that I did on the last occasion this Bill was in the Committee stage and that is the reason I will be moving the same amendment to this Bill in the Committee stage. It will provide for the Senate the scrutiny which, as Senator Macklin mentioned on a previous occasion, is important. In other words, prior to any institution being forced to impose fees the determination made by the Minister would need to be placed before both Houses of Parliament, and either House of Parliament would have the right to disallow that determination by the Minister. In that way we would have the best of both worlds. If, for example, the Minister included in that determination a requirement for the imposition of fees, say for higher degree students or those meal ticket students I was referring to, of course this chamber could disallow it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill precludes extending it to categories of students other than those who are defined.

—It does, of course. Senator Teague indicated that the Bill already precludes certain students, including those attempting to obtain their first degree. So I put it to the Senate that we again have the opportunity of exercising our proper scrutiny-our proper audit and control functions-in a manner consistent with the review rights of this chamber, but nevertheless providing the ultimate protection against the imposition by the Government of unwanted fees; fees that by definition are not desired by the majority in this chamber. If I read things correctly, no such fees would be able to be implemented. In those circumstances, and only in those circumstances, it is my intention to vote for the second reading of all these Bills. I will reconsider my position in respect of the two fees Bills in the event of my amendment being defeated at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to Senator Ryan's amendment. I am in a difficult situation in that I would like to have seen it in the form of a suggestion, along the lines that the Minister for Education consider paragraphs (1), (2) and (3). SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three education Bills, the first being the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 (No. 2), the second being the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and the third being the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. I will deal with them separately and I will be brief because there has been extensive debate in this chamber before on the subject matter. The first Bill has now been separated so that it does not contain the fee component.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has moved an amendment relating to the amalgamation of universities and colleges. The Government will oppose that amendment. Let me make it perfectly clear to the Senate that the principle of these amalgamations came as a recommendation from an expert technical academic body, the Tertiary Education Commission, which was set up as an advisory body to the Government, to the Parliament and the people of Australia. The Tertiary Education Commission is an apolitical body headed by one of the great educationists of Australia, Professor Peter Karmel, a man whom both sides of politics have relied upon for judgments. The Commission is associated with three councils-the Universities Council, the Advanced Education Council and the Technical and Further Education Council-again with technical and expert people. It is very important indeed to understand that the amalgamations as a principle were recommended; in other words, the Government, in bringing forward its requirement for the consolidation of 30 colleges of advanced education, had taken account of specialist advice. The Tertiary Education Commission, in volume 1 of its report for 1982-84 recommended that institutions which are predominantly concerned with teacher education be consolidated into larger units. That is the basis for what has happened. The Government also recognised the need for a re-allocation of resources in education away from teacher training and towards the technologies and business studies. So the principle is one that was recommended by an expert academic body.

Senator Ryan directed her attention primarily to the Townsville College of Advanced Education and the James Cook University and suggested that some bad education principles were involved. I direct her attention to the fact that the Tertiary Education Commission in its recent report supported the integration in north Queensland of the two institutions under a single governing body on the grounds that-to quote its words-'this would produce the best quality of education and the widest ranges of choices for students'.

Senator Ryan directed her attention to the fact that State governments have some responsibility for courses. Education, as she must know, is in fact constitutionally a State matter. The provision of courses within all institutions can be under the total sovereignty of the States because they have a constitutional responsibility in this respect. There is absolutely nothing at all new about that situation. When universities were set up around Australia, the State governments indicated the faculties to be established. In fact, when the colleges were set up, the State governments had their say. There is a bilateral discussion between the States and the Commonwealth as to courses. There is nothing new at all in governments deciding what courses will be undertaken. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that there is something politically wrong, that there is some tainting of academic freedom in governments indicating the courses. I repeat to the Senate that academic freedom is the right of teachers to teach and students to learn freely without an imposition from outside of dogma or doctrines whether false or accurate in themselves. It is in the detail of what is taught, in the philosophies, the dogmas and the doctrines of what is taught, that freedom exists and there is no taint of that at all. Let me make it clear that there is nothing new at all and that what is happening in respect of amalgamations comes from an expert academic body. So much for the first part of the honourable senator's speech.

As to the second part, the approach has been that there is an opposition to fees. It has been widely argued that, if we impose fees, we will reduce access to education and therefore lower the quality and quantity of people coming forward. Attention has also been drawn to that fact that Australia has fewer people in the higher tertiary education situation than have some other countries. But the fallacy of the argument that is being put forward is this: In almost every other country, very heavy fees are imposed at first, second and higher degree levels. Those fees do not debar people from moving into the university and tertiary education systems. What is more, few if any other countries at the primary degree level not only provide education without fees but also provide assistance through a scheme such as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.

The provision of a course with no fees and a supporting allowance to students is almost unique in the world. So, if we are talking about barriers, this country in that regard has fewer barriers than almost any country with which we might wish to compare ourselves. If we are not attracting people to this part of the education system, the fault lies somewhere down the scale. One of the things to be looked at, and to be looked at very carefully-and this is not relevant to the Bills before us-is that in Australia the retention level between the ages 15 and 19 years sadly is lower than those in many other countries. It is not within the higher situation that the fault lies.

So the imposition of fees on those undertaking higher degrees certainly will not reduce access if in fact it has not done so overseas. It has been suggested that the Government ought to have brought in these two Bills in the way it has done now in the first place. I make it clear that there is no constitutional power standing alone for the Commonwealth to impose fees. Therefore it cannot bring in a separate Bill imposing fees. The imposition of fees rests on section 96 of the Constitution, which relates to specific grants. That must lean upon the main Bill itself. In every one of the States grants Bills that has come before there has been a section 96 imposition. There was nothing new in what we did and the first Bill, which removed the provision of fees, said that we would give the universities and colleges money only if they did not impose fees. That was contained in the one Bill.

I have viewed Senator Harradine's amendment. When last that amendment came before the Senate I was able to indicate that the Government was willing to consider supporting the disallowance principle in place of the proposed amendment to the original Bill but, sadly for Senator Harradine, his amendment applies not to the first Bill presented here tonight but to the second Bill. I understand it has been indicated that the second Bill will not get into the Committee stage because the intention of the Opposition, sadly enough, is to defeat it at the second reading. So the Committee stage will not apply and therefore the amendment will be irrelevant. I indicate that if it were moved in the Committee stage the Government would support it. I sum up simply by saying that what we are doing on amalgamations is in line with advice and what we are doing in regard to fees is minor compared with what is being done overseas. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills replace earlier Bills dated 18 August which were passed by the House of Representatives. They have passed the first reading stage in the Senate and the Minister for National Develpoment and Energy (Senator Carrick) has delivered his second reading speech. The Opposition did not oppose the first set of Bills because they were an improvement on the existing means by which fees were collected from television and broadcasting stations. The schemes which were apparent in the first set of Bills introduced provided a greater amount of equity. For example, under the proposals the licence holders with the smallest revenues would pay less than they did under the existing legislation and those with the largest revenues would pay more than they did under the existing legislation. So a principle of equity was introduced into the legislation. The Opposition accepts that licence holders ought to be taxed in accordance with the access which they have to the airways. There is an economic rent involved in the holding of these licences and thus the public should get a return.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say at the outset of my remarks that the Australian Labor Party accepts that profitability in the broadcasting industry is very important. It says that it is a necessary but perhaps not sufficient condition for providing good programming. If we look at the Australian commercial television industry over the last ten years or so I think it is probably fair to argue that over the last four or five years programming has shown a steady improvement. One of the reasons for that steady improvement in the last four or five years is that television stations have become more viable in an economic sense and have been able to spend more money on Australian programming. The levels of Australian content on Ausralian television are probably better than they have ever been before. So the notion that profitability in the industry is important is basic to our view that good programs will result in part, although it may not be a sufficient condition for good programming in total. We have the same attitude to the introduction of cable television in Australia.

For these reasons we are not opposing these Bills. A sufficiently superficial and trivial charge is involved. But I want to draw attention to some important aspects in the changes in this legislation. The Senate will recall that a set of Bills dealing with licence fees for broadcasting stations was passed by the House of Representatives and introduced into the Senate. Then something happened and the Government decided not to go on with that scheme of imposing a new system of charges on television and broadcasting stations in respect of the licences they hold. We are rather bemused as to why the Government suddenly abandoned this series of legislation which arose from the Budget. It was mentioned in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). We are bemused that sudden changes could be made to a Budget which has been described by this Government as a Budget of great integrity. I use the word 'bemused'. Perhaps it is the wrong word. The Oxford English Dictionary defines the word 'bemused' as 'stupefied' or 'confused'. I do not think we are stupefied. Nothing Government members have done in the Senate this session reveals stupefication on behalf of anybody but themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stupefaction.

—I do not know whether the word is 'stupefaction'. I think 'stupefication' will do. The point is very clear. Whichever is the correct word, it applies to the Government rather than to us. The point I am making is simply that although we are neither stupefied nor confused by what the Government has done in this change of tack, we are, in a strange way, wryly amused. We understand precisely what has happened. Let me tell the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) what has happened in relation to the television licence fees which the Government announced in the Budget. Nothing illustrates better what the Fraser Government is about in the way it does business, if that is the appropriate expression, in Australia than this legislation. The Government of Malcolm Fraser moves in a most extraordinary way its wonders to perform. As I said, this legislation illustrates that very much.
—Is that Presbyterian?

—Again and again Senator Collard and his colleagues have told us how important is the integrity of a Fraser Budget. In this case representations were made on behalf of the big television stations to change the system of collecting licence fees. The macho, tough Government of Malcolm Fraser caved in when the big television channels asked for a change in the formula under which licence fees are collected. When representations come to this Government from organisations it perceives as being important to its electoral success, in other words, from organisations it fears and which have, in this Fraser Government society, the character of medieval private armies of which the Government is afraid, it caves in and the integrity of the Budget, which is talked about so often disappears.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is very tough on matters such as sales tax. It will not give in on sales tax on shoes for children or building materials for new home buyers. It will not give in on the yawning deposit gap and high interest rates for new home buyers. It will not give in on sales tax on books, newspapers and periodicals. It will not give in on any of the areas which affect the living standards of the average Australian. To put it in the terms of a well-known American expression, the moment the media proprietors in Australia say 'frog' the Fraser Government jumps, and it has jumped on this occasion to accommodate those interests. That is why we have this bizarre situation of legislation being withdrawn from the Senate and new legislation being brought in which satisfies particular media proprietors. When it comes to doing favours for great and powerful friends, the flexibility of the Fraser Government is unbounded. No doubt it would be called accommodating to political realities.

This Bill sets a limit of 7.5 per cent of gross earnings for television and 5 per cent for radio. For example, for television the limit cuts out at about $47m which is 7.5 per cent of gross earnings of a television station. By our calculations the changes will involve a cost to revenue of some $100,000 this year. This is $100,000 which the Government is prepared to throw back to those companies but which it is not prepared to throw back to all sorts of other things important to this community and to the majority of Australian people. The loss to revenue by 1983-84 could possibly be $3m when a number of Sydney and Melbourne stations will exceed the cut in point. I make the point that this affects only the big proprietors; for example, it affects the Channel 9 network for Kerry Packer, the most profitable and best run television network in Australia.

The changes to the legislation do not affect the television industry generally; they affect the high fliers, the high profit earners. I would doubt very much the claims of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) that the Government reconsidered the measures in the light of representations from the broadcasting and television industry. I do not think the broadcasting and television industry was concerned about these proposals. I think the 9 network was concerned about these proposals, as were one or two of the other major networks. I think the representations which altered this Budget of the Fraser Government came from a few well placed individuals representing the biggest stations.

My scenario of what happened is this: Some of the big media proprietors were concerned about sales tax on books, periodicals and newspapers. They expressed their concern to the Government. I think the Government said: 'We can't do anything about that without losing face so can we do a trade off with you and do something about broadcasting licence fees instead?' That is what has happened in the context of this legislation. The effect will not be felt equally throughout the industry. It is of concern to the major stations only. A question of principle relating to the conduct of this Government is contained in this legislation. In a sense that is all that is really important about it. We, when in government, will have the opportunity to look at licence fees again as indeed this Government has the right, so long as it survives, to look at licence fees again. Probably with increased profitability it will be something that governments of all political persuasions will want to do.

This Bill represents incompetence, muddleheadedness, ad hockery and a preparedness to reverse fundamental decisions, as they were described, on behalf of particular individuals of considerable wealth in this community. It represents in a sense a further question mark over the credibility of the Minister for Communications. There are so many question marks over his head he looks like a row of asterisks at the end of a sentence. Of all the administrations of this Government there is no more incredible, rather than credible, administration than that of the Minister for Communications.

Why have decisions been made by this Government against the advice of the Department of Communications and the Treasury in areas such as that affecting the decision as to whether Telecom Australia should develop videotex? Why have those decisions been made against the advice of departments and of everybody concerned with the proper development of industry such as that in Australia and, of course, at the final instigation of the Minister? Why were these changes made? What representations were made to the Department of Communications about these changes on behalf of the big television proprietors? Was it all done in a back bar of the Australia Club in Sydney? That is where I suspect it happened. If it happened there the Minister for Communications would be running true to form-not that I think he is a drinker; that is about the only thing that he does not do. However, what concerns one about this, the real argument that emerges from this sort of legislation is how long this country will tolerate this sort of thing going on without public declaration of donations to political parties. That is what it is all about. That is how this Government operates in areas such as this. Donations to the Liberal Party of Australia are the motivation for these crazy decisions about communications policy.

Until we get quite clear guidelines about the disclosure of funds donated to political parties, the Minister for Communications and other Ministers in this Government will not be above suspicion. That is the only conclusion that people can draw when they observe a series of irrational decisions made contrary to the public interest. People are entitled to know why Lord Howe Island can get a telephone connection years ahead of the time that would have applied under the priorities determined by Telecom Australia. Why did the Minister for Communications decide to make an alteration to the capital works priorities in the margin of a document from Telecom in his own well-known handwriting? Why did he do that? Why was the decision made that Telecom could no longer operate Videotex but that it should be given to the Channel 9 people, Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd and the Myer Emporium Ltd? Why were these decisions made? They are not rational decisions. They are not decisions made in the public interest. They are decisions which raise this query: Is it not about time that Australia had very clear and specific legislation on the disclosure of information concerning donations to political parties and members of political parties? When we get those things straightened out there will be much less temptation. There will be much better legislation because there will be much more determination to see that these things happen in the public interest rather than against it.

We reluctantly indicate that we will not oppose these Bills. They are not terribly important. They are only important as an indication of the Fraser Government's total incredibility, or lack of credibility, on these issues. They are another symbolic indication of what this Government is all about. I understand that Senator Siddons, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of these Bills. I indicate now that we will support that amendment. It will express an opinion about another sector of the broadcasting industry which has been grossly neglected by this Government and we support that opinion. Apart from that, we do not oppose these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, human nature being what it is, the Australian Democrats were naturally very suspicious about the Government's intention in introducing the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill 1981 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bills 1981 to alter the formula for raising television and broadcasting licence fees. Those who have studied the Bills will have seen that they are, in fact, a mathematician's delight. The formulas incorporated in the Bills for calculating the fees to be levied on broadcasting stations are almost incomprehensible to the casual observer.

SPEECH.PARA: We have done our best to grapple with the arithmetic of these Bills. The Government will be pleased to hear that we believe the net result is that there is very little difference between the amount of revenue the Government would raise under the new Bills and the amount it would have raised under the previous Bills which were introduced on 18 August this year. It is clear that the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill has been drafted with a particular organisation in mind. Why else would the ceiling come into operation at a point which almost equates the gross revenue of the Channel 9 network this year?

What is worrying us to some degree, if our calculations are correct, is that the amount of revenue that the Government will be raising will be only slightly more than it would have been under the old formula. We approve of a ceiling. The old formula had a percentage of gross earnings which rose as the gross earnings rose. For instance, with a gross revenue of $1m, the percentage for the fee was 8.45 per cent. So, theoretically, if the broadcasters were to pay a continually escalating percentage of their gross revenue, it would be possible for 100 per cent of gross revenue to be payable to the Government, which obviously is absurd. We approve of the proposal for an upper ceiling. If one works through the mathematics of the formula, it seems that the revenue due to the Government will not be greatly altered. Therefore, we join with the Australian Labor Party in not opposing the new Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you say you support them? Come on; take a deep breath and say it.

—If that makes Senator Baume happier, we support them. However, we draw attention to the fact that the Government, as it indicated in the Budget, will be raising about $10m under these Bills. Therefore, it is significant to point to an election promise that the Government is not fulfilling. I refer to its promise to fund public television in this financial year. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wrote a letter to the Public Broadcasting Association indicating that the Government would call for licences for public television during this financial year. So far that has not been done. We ask: why?

SPEECH.PARA: In our view, public television is a very worthwhile objective. It allows people who are not professionals to have access to a medium whereby they can communicate with the public at large and provide a service which is not covered currently by commercial, national or multicultural television.

A complementary service of public television could include such things as cultural development in which category we would put variety and dance, theatre performances, the visual arts and crafts, and local independent and creative films. It could cover such things as special needs programs. It could cover a diversity of needs for such people as the deaf and dumb, the disabled, the aged, youth, low income earners, environmentalists, those interested in minority sports, Aboriginal women and so forth. Public television could cover educational and educative programs. Above all, it could act as a means of better communication between regional and ethnic groups within the community.

The Public Broadcasting Association proposed that it would need government funding for the first five years only and after that would be self-supporting. The cost to the Government was estimated at $7m. It was an election promise that has not been kept so far. It is for this reason that we propose to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading asking the Government to honour this election promise.

I suggest at this stage one line of development which could, in fact, save the Government a certain amount of revenue and also develop a new form of communication. I refer to radiated subscription television, or pay television as it is more commonly known. If the Government were to introduce pay television immediately and delay such developments as cable television, which will cost in the order of $1 billion to $1.5 billion, it could, in addition to giving the public the benefit of high quality programs that pay television would ensure, also fund public television much more cheaply. At least, only two stations would be necessary to make pay television commercially viable. In addition, pay television needs the air waves only between the hours of 6 p.m. and 11 p.m. The rest of the time those two channels could be available for public television and they could be available in the early hours of the morning for transmitting special educational programs which could be videotape recorded for the schools that needed them.

I conclude by suggesting delaying the introduction of cable television, immediately introducing pay television-radiated subscription television-and making two channels available for commercial purposes for pay television while requiring that those channels be available for public television and for educational purposes, would achieve many worthwhile objectives at minimal cost to government revenue. SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:
', but the Senate requests the Government to honour its election pledge on public television and to call for licences for public television stations before 30 June 1982'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill. What has emerged in this debate is that there is support for these Bills from both sides of the chamber. The only argument really seems to be at the margins. The argument seems to be only as to what the upper level of the licence fee rate should be. I notice that the Australian Democrats have given their overt support to the imposition of a ceiling on the rate of licence fees. I acknowledge that this is the line the Government is taking. Senator Button developed an argument suggesting that there was some kind of conspiracy or that some kind of private deal was done. In fact, the reason for the alteration in the formula is that there was a re-consideration in the light of the representations from industry, from the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the organisations representing broadcasters and television stations. The last increase, in 1977, was a 20 per cent across the board increase. This increase being proposed now is to be reviewed in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the maximum rate of 7.5 per cent for television stations might have risen under the previously announced formula to perhaps 7.7 per cent or a little higher. The rates being proposed are only marginally different. As for the 5 per cent rate for radio broadcasting stations, I understand that at present no station has reached that rate. The rate will still be expressed as a percentage of gross earnings. It is only the rate which will not rise above a certain figure. The amount of fee payable will rise above a certain figure. The amount of fee payable will rise as gross earnings rise. Therefore, it is wrong to say that a lid is being put on the fees. A lid is being put on the rate at which the fee is to be paid. That is the point that Senator Siddons brought out in his speech, one which we also want to bring out. The upper limits do not mean that licence fees will remain static. They mean that above a certain level the rate of the licence fee will remain static. Of course, as gross earnings rise, the amount of revenue, the amount payable by stations, will rise.

The amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, which we understand will have the support of the Australian Labor Party, seeks to add certain words to the end of the motion that the Bill be read a second time. I wish to make two points. An election commitment is an election commitment. The Government can be judged eventually on whether it honours its commitment. I am able to report on the kinds of activities which have taken place so far and which it is envisaged will take place in the near future. Guidelines for public Television are being prepared by the Department of Communications. It is expected that they will be submitted to the Government for consideration shortly. The guidelines are needed first. It is unfortunate that the process of preparation has been a lengthy one, but honourable senators will appreciate the need for full consultation with the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia and other industry bodies and consideration of all the issues before the Government approves the guidelines. I put it to the honourable senators that, with the best will in the world, the guidelines have to be appropriate before we can proceed. Once the guidelines are issued, planning proposals for public television services may be developed and submitted for consideration in the normal way; that is, through the planning processes of the Department of Communications and the licensing procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The guidelines will open the way for the calling of licences for public television. The Government believes the setting of a mandatory date-the part of the amendment which we do not find acceptable-for such action as is proposed by the amendment could be counterproductive and might unnecessarily complicate the planning process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original undertaking was that licences would be called by the first quarter of 1981; that was in writing.

—We are taking action to implement that promise. I put it to honourable senators that to put that date on it may not be in the long term public interest. For that reason, we will oppose the amendment, while emphasising once again that the substance of the amendment-that the Government has a commitment to go down that road of development-is one to which we still adhere and which we still intend to honour. I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has replied to the debate. I was outside the chamber for just a couple of minutes and had expected Senator Siddons to continue. I seek leave--
—Leave is not required. The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, moved the second reading motion and Senator Peter Baume has responded. The debate has not been closed.

—I simply want to make a couple of points on the subject of broadcasting in Australia. The Senate will recall that earlier this year I spoke in particular about the quality of broadcasting. I also raised questions with the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and have recently been provided with an answer. I will be communicating further with the Minister in respect of that answer. However, the subject of cable and subscription television was raised during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to add my comments in regard to this matter because during the past few months the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has been hearing public evidence on the social, economic, technical and other implications involved if subscription television is to be introduced in Australia. That has been the decision and that is what is occuring. But, at the same time, the public can expect, and is already being bombarded with, propaganda on the benefits of subscription television. National and international entrepreneurs know that there are fortunes to be made from the new networks which, in the United States, offer viewers just about everything from live concerts and sport to pornography and mindless violence. These entrepreneurs will tell one also how cable television can offer one shopping, banking and information receival services. But they will not tell one that advances in telecommunications technology will make these add-on facilities available much more quickly and cheaply through telephone attachments.

Before the inquiry proceeds much further the Government must announce its attitude on two vital questions which are relevant to the introduction of subscription television. The two issues I refer to are quality and cost. On the subject of quality, the viewing public must be sceptical of the Government's resolve. Despite what Senator Button said in his speech, the fact is that successive governments have deliberately allowed the question of the monitoring of television standards to be pushed into the background. I have referred previously to the fact that the Broadcasting Information Office which was, with great fanfare, to have assumed the role of receiving and investigating complaints from the public has, in fact, effectively received the chop from the razor gang. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has clear powers under the Broadcasting and Television Act to set and enforce program standards, and so has the Minister. So, let us have a bit of action in this field before we move on to other areas. Let us have a bit of action also in respect of some of the public broadcasting stations and some of the FM stations that broadcast material and abuse the airwaves that they are licensed to use.

I oppose the amendment to the Bill because I believe that we have a job to do with what we have got already before we go into other areas. We have to look at the quality of existing services rather than extending into other areas immediately. I believe we should have some action in this field. Then the public might believe assurances which no doubt will fall from the lips of the Government and the Minister about protection of the public from exploitation. I mention that some figures that have been developed already in respect of the cost of subscription television are astronomical. The cost of laying cables for Sydney has been estimated at $400m. I ask the Senate: Can we, as a nation, really afford this at this point? In any event developments in satellite technology may yet again revolutionise communications of which broadcasting is a part. Yet, as I understand it, satellite broadcasting is not even a part of the Tribunal's current inquiry. By waiting a little longer for colour television Australia learnt from the costly technical mistakes of other countries. In my view it would be prudent to wait and to use the time to improve the quality and standards of our existing broadcasting and television services. I use this opportunity to make those points and to urge upon the Government the need to ensure quality in existing broadcasting facilities. Because of that I oppose at this stage the amendment that has been moved.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should be given specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions.
(2) That the President be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the applications have been presented to the Committee for its consideration.

The Opposition has been increasingly concerned at developments which affect the direction, staffing and effectiveness of the Parliamentary Library. This is of particular concern because the Library is the most important, single resource at the disposal of honourable members and honourable senators of all parties, opposition and government. In recent years the Library has been the centre of internal conflict and controversy over the range of services which it makes available to members. There have been complaints of authoritarian control over the staff, of patronage, and of a refusal to consult the senior officers about new technology or the organisation of different sections of the Library as a whole. The Government has significantly reduced the allocation of money available to the Library. Now there is disquiet about the pending appointment of a new Librarian and the merging of three of the five departments of the Parliament. The appointment of a new Librarian ought to be a subject of the keenest interest to all members of parliament. It certainly is a subject in which the Opposition and, we believe, other opposition parties have the keenest interest. It ought to be a matter of general concern. Unfortunately, however, there seems to be a reluctance by the Presiding Officers to consult with honourable members and honourable senators. Mr President, I am fully appreciative of the fact that you are a relatively new Presiding Officer and the complaints go back much further than that. I will distinguish the situations to which I refer.

It would be very unfortunate if there were substance in the suggestions being made that the delay in appointing a new Librarian, which went on for some time, was due to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sir Billy Snedden, dragging his feet on the issue. I should point out that only last weekend advertisements appeared in national newspapers, as I understand, now advertising for a new Librarian for the Parliamentary Library. I wish to refer to those advertisements in a moment. This motion is being brought to the attention of the Senate and the Parliament at this stage because it gives an opportunity for an assurance by the President that he and the Speaker of the House of Representatives do not propose to appoint a new Parliamentary Librarian during the parliamentary recess without seeking the views of members and senators of this Parliament. The appointment of a Parliamentary Librarian should be made on a scrupulously non-party basis. After all, it is a position of great sensitivity; one which goes to the very heart of how effectively this Parliament functions.

Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber have been in government for many years. No doubt that is a nice position to be in. But surely it must make them feel better, being in government, when they are able to point to a well informed and well briefed opposition, well informed and well briefed members of the Australian Democrats, and a well informed and well briefed Senator Harradine-when they see what a competent array of people they have against them-and know that they have been chosen by the electorate in spite of that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are feeling mighty sick on this side at the moment.

—I am sorry about that. I will just announce to the people of Australia that Senator Walters is feeling mighty sick. I do not know what that is all about. No doubt people will draw their own conclusions and relieve the honourable senator of her senatorial burdens at the next election. The point I am making is that there is an opportunity here for the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate to give some assurances about the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian. It is important to both Government and Opposition senators that they be well informed as a result of the facility of the Parliamentary Library.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years there have been two senior officers of the Parliamentary Library, one of whom became the Librarian, who have had close links with the Australian intelligence community. When I say 'the Australian intelligence community' I do not mean people with higher than average intellect. That would be welcome in any librarian. When I say 'the Australian intelligence community' I mean snoops. I suppose there is a place for snoops in all societies but the last place where we should find snoops from security services is in the library of a national parliament. However many honourable senators want to have-that is, pay your money and take your choice-they should not be in the Australian Parliamentary Library.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is terrible.
—Senator Walters said that is terrible. I have made a point with her at last. I am glad she agrees with that view.
—That is a terrible thing to say.
