SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, another matter which is of concern to the Opposition, and it is an associated matter, is the indication that the five departments of the Parliament are likely to be reduced to three. It is suggested that the Joint House Department, Hansard and the Library should be amalgamated. That suggestion was put clearly to an Estimates Committee in the House of Representatives on 8 September by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sir Billy Snedden. Mr Speaker, in the course of his statement, said that the current head of the Joint House Department, Mr Jorgensen, was a departmental head 'of great quality'. There is concern amongst many parliamentarians that this might mean that Mr Jorgensen, at the initiative of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will be placed in control of these three departments. Frankly, members of the Australian Labor Party believe that there should be more consultation if such a decision were to be made because they do not have the highest confidence in the qualifications of Mr Jorgensen and in his capacity to handle and direct staff, as they have certainty about the question of his political neutrality. Mr Jorgensen's background in the business world as a director of the failed Palmdale Insurance Ltd and as Executive Director of the Master Builders Association raised some questions in the minds of members of parliament on this side as to whether he is the appropriate person to be appointed to that position. Yet when one looks at Mr Speaker's answer in the House of Representatives one gets at least the suggestion that he is in mind for such an appointment. What consultation is there to be with members of parliament if that decision is to be made? What confidence will members of parliament have in that decision and in the integrity and efficiency of the administration of the Library if such a decision is made without any consultation?

Once again we trust, Mr President, that you and Mr Speaker will do us the courtesy of canvassing our views before any new department is created and certainly before any new head is appointed to such a newly created department. I am not saying by that that we would oppose the suggestion for the amalgamation of those three departments, that it is necessarily and intrinsically wrong. All we would like to do is to record with you the view that there is concern about it and that there would be no confidence about a decision which was made without at least a modicum of appropriate discussion with a large and significant group of parliamentarians who may be affected by that decision.

We are also somewhat suspicious about the way in which the Government has dealt with the financial allocation to the Parliamentary Library. Honourable senators should be aware of the following developments. Firstly, the Library's permanent staff has been reduced by 2 per cent and three temporary positions are to be abolished. These cuts are to be made by the end of the current financial year. That contrasts with the 2 per cent reduction over two years which was recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions-the so-called razor gang. So, in fact, the cuts in the Library's staff are in excess of the recommendations of the razor gang. Secondly, there has been a growth in the number of senior positions in the Library administration, so these cutbacks will tend to make the Library top heavy rather than balanced in its staffing requirements. Thirdly, the administrative expenditure effectively has been cut by 12 per cent, or 2.6 per cent more than for all Commonwealth departments.

The 12 per cent cut represents a reduction in real terms of 22 per cent. This will be particularly severe in some areas. It has been estimated, for example, that the allocation for books has been cut by 46 per cent, for photocopying by 44 per cent, computer search by 22 per cent, photocopying stores by 30 per cent, microfilming by 63 per cent and postage by 47 per cent. All of those details are matters which affect the day to day work, and the freedom to indulge in that work in an intelligent and informed way, of members of this Parliament. They are matters which should be matters of concern to all parliamentarians; astute at looking after their salaries when salary claims come along, they should also be astute at looking after their working conditions when matters of conditions come to the fore in discussions in this Parliament. The Library, with those cuts, will not be able to maintain standards and the fault for this lies with the Government. It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when in Opposition was a notoriously heavy user of the Parliamentary Library services. He knows better than anyone else the damage that can be done to any Opposition by starving it and other non-government members of the research services of the Parliamentary Library.

Mr President, briefly I press the Senate and you to agree to this course of action. Firstly, I ask that you press for the restoration of the money that has been taken away from the Library. It will be too late to have it restored in Additional Estimates. It should be made part of the Advance to the Minister for Finance so that it would be available promptly. If it returns in the Additional Estimates it will not be available until perhaps May of next year. Secondly, there should be formal consultation by the Presiding Officers with the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and Government back benchers before decisions are made, firstly, about the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian, secondly, about the amalgamation of the Joint House Department, Hansard, and the Parliamentary Library and, thirdly, about the appointment of a person to head such an amalgamated department. We are saying that members of parliament should be consulted about those issues because they are issues which go to the heart and integrity of the capacity of members of parliament to perform their work effectively, intelligently and well.

I commend the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing chaired by Senator Jessop. The Jessop report, as it is now coming to be called, made it clear that the five parliamentary departments should not be regarded as an ordinary annual service of the Government. It therefore follows that staffing of those departments should be under the control of the Presiding Officers and the committees proposed in Senator Jessop's report. In view of the fact that three vital staff positions currently are under threat and two of the unions concerned have taken a strong stand on this matter, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press release by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the Professional Officers Association relating to this issue.

PARLIAMENTARY LIBRARY STAFF CUTBACKS ''THREATEN INDEPENDENCE OF PARLIAMENT'', SAY PS UNIONS

Information and Research Services for all Members of Parliament will be seriously jeopardised by proposed Government-imposed staff cutbacks in the Parliamentary Library, according to a joint statement issued today, by Mary Wilson, Industrial Officer ACOA and Jeff Gordon, Industrial Officer POA.

Both unions said that the Public Service Board had told the Parliamentary Library management to show cause why it should not lose three staff positions. Areas where staff could be lost included Science Information and Research and Economics Research. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight on the subject of the motor vehicle industry and tariffs. I am doing so on the adjournment because of the decision that is anticipated to come down from the Government during the recess on that subject and its importance to South Australia, together with the fact that this is likely to be the only opportunity that I will have to address the subject. The logical starting point to any discussion of government assistance to the motor vehicle industry is the Industries Assistance Commission draft report on post-1984 assistance. The report is that of an independent commission with a great deal of expertise. The findings are based on submissions made by all major parties to the debate and its own research. Prima facie it therefore must be treated with respect. I deplore those elements within the industry which call for the Commission to be disbanded simply because it is reaching conclusions inconsistent with their views. The input of objectivity provided by the Commission is immensely valuable to a highly complex subject and must be preserved. It must, however, be remembered that the brief of the Commission is limited. It reports to its terms of reference. Other factors may well have to be taken into account in consideration of the implementation of its recommendations. Such factors as social consequence, which the Commission is unable to quantify, require political judgment. Implementation would require a change in political philosophy from that under which the motor vehicle industry in Australia has developed to date.

SPEECH.PARA: The major findings of the Commission that are of particular importance I will summarise as follows: Firstly, the industry is one of Australia's highest cost activities, receiving three to four times the assistance afforded to manufacturing industry generally. Put at a sum in excess of $1 billion per year, assistance is estimated to have roughly doubled in the last five years. Secondly, despite such massive community support, competitiveness and employment have declined. Thirdly, the lack of competitiveness is largely due to low volumes of component production and vehicle assembly in Australia compared with overseas operators. Consequently, there has been limited exploitation of the benefits of economies of scale, specialisation and attendant advanced technology. Fourthly, the size and shape of the local industry shall be determined mainly by marketplace preference and international comparative advantage rather than by high levels and complex forms of assistance. Fifthly, it is inevitable that such adjustment would have adverse effects on existing employment and investment in some sections of the industry but there would be gains to the community generally through lower vehicle prices and improved efficiency of resource use.

On the basis of such findings the IAC recommended gradual reduction of protection so that by 1990 the level would be similar to that afforded in the early 1970s. It would still be high, giving the Australian produced product a 35 per cent cost advantage, but it would be more in line with that available to manufacturing industry generally. Specifically, the three recommendations that I consider to be of the greatest importance are as follows: Firstly, that the quotas or market share requirements which guarantee the Australian car industry 80 per cent of the total market, subject to no test of efficiency, be cut out in 1985. Secondly, that to provide extra cushioning for that change, tariffs on imported cars and knocked down vehicle parts be increased to 60 per cent in 1985 but that they then be gradually reduced to 35 per cent by 1990. Thirdly, that the export facilitation scheme, which commences in 1982, be modified so that vehicle manufacturers would be able to import 10 per cent of parts duty free and a further 7.5 per cent subject to export performance. Component producers would be entitled to duty free by-law credits on the basis of export performance to the extent of 20 per cent. The real crux of the report is summarised at page 10 which states:

It is already evident, from labour shedding and losses of existing investments, that maintaining the status quo cannot avoid disruptions. The longer the local industry is assisted to delay confrontation with its poor competitive and structural position, the more likely it is that the industries of other countries will adjust to changing market circumstances and become more competitive relative to Australian industry.

The IAC report and the whole debate on protection in relation to the motor vehicle industry must be put in the context of the immensely important role that the industry currently plays in the Australian community. Clearly, it is the core of Australia's manufacturing industry. In 1979-80 it accounted for approximately 7 per cent of all manufacturing employment in the country-about 80,000 employees. It also represented approximately 10 per cent of total manufacturing investment or about $250m of investment in that year.

While it is argued that a reduction in protection will result in better resource use and therefore new employment opportunities, it must nevertheless be accepted that in any major restructuring proposal a great deal of employment is at risk. Furthermore, when assessing the risk factor it is worth noting that the motor vehicle manufacturing centres in Australia are not widely distributed. South Australia and Victoria together contain 90 per cent of the motor vehicle manufacturing presence in Australia. From South Australia's point of view, about 18,000 people are directly employed in vehicle making and about 94 component-making businesses employ another 12,000 people whose employment is dependent upon the industry. Therefore, while employment opportunities may improve elsewhere because of better resource allocation, South Australia and Victoria could face massive unemployment problems. Furthermore, Australian Bureau of Statistics figures based on the 1976 census show that 64 per cent of those employed in the car manufacturing sector are overseas born. Of those, 75 per cent have no technical or trade qualifications. Some 66 per cent of the Australian-born work-force employed in this sector has no trade or technical qualification. Alternative employment for this section of the community could not easily be found, even with better resource allocation. Thus the risk factor for South Australian employment is extremely high and explains the somewhat emotive terms in which the debate has been pursued.

The importance of the industry to other areas of production similarly is not to be underestimated. There is little doubt that the motor vehicle industry plays a most significant role in the economy as a major consumer of materials such as steel, plastics, rubber, glass, textiles and paint. Furthermore, although Australians may be technically innovative, a nation with little manufacturing industry has no incentive to develop new skills and technical knowledge. Thus the risks if Australia ceases to have a motor vehicle manufacturing capacity are considerable and must weigh heavily on the mind of government. It is clear that we can now produce vehicles in competition on the open market with Japan. It is therefore argued that we should be importing more vehicles and exporting to their countries of origin that which we more efficiently produce. However, this assumes an international free market which simply does not exist.

All motor manufacturing countries have restrictions on imports. Thus, notwithstanding what may be correct economic theory regarding the benefits of competition and efficiency, the reality of the world motor industry is that protection of local vehicle manufacturers is the norm rather than the exception. Such restrictions take different forms. They may take the form of explicit market sharing agreements such as those of France which limits the Japanese share of its car market to 3 per cent, or of Italy, which restricts Japanese car imports to only 2,000 vehicles a year; implicit market sharing agreements such as that imposed by the United States of America; monetary policies such as that of Japan; environmental factors such as in France; or high tariffs such as in Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela, which have duty regimes for imported vehicles ranging from 85 per cent to 205 per cent.

This is not intended to justify the present level of protection afforded the Australian industry but merely to make the point that changes in the assistance package will be made in a less than competitive world. In actual fact, according to evidence submitted last year to the trade sub-committee-of the powerful Ways and Means Committee of the United States Senate, Australia is second only to the United States in the share of the market allowed for Japanese vehicles. The Japanese share of the Australian market was 15.2 per cent and of the American market 16.6 per cent. Thus in overall protection we are not particularly out of step but rather more generous to imports than are some countries. Furthermore, and particularly important, it should never be forgotten that Japan's industry has grown rapidly and effectively in the shelter of a highly protected environment. That, I believe, gives a hint of the answer to Australia's problems.

To analyse the situation further one must ask why substantial Government support is necessary even to retain the status quo within the Australian industry. Primarily, small production runs have prevented Australian manufacturers achieving economies of scale. We have eight passenger vehicle manufacturers producing 19 basic models for a relatively small domestic market of from 450,000 to 475,000 new cars a year. The combined United States of America-Japan annual production run of 18 million cars a year indicates the degree of the disability experienced by the Australian motor vehicle industry. In that production environment our competitive position has worsened, with a slow down in market expansion due principally to a decline in world economic activity and rising oil prices. The shift in world demand away from Australia's traditional larger six and eight cylinder passenger vehicles has meant huge costs in redesign and new tooling. Increased oil prices have required a new technology range of cars, again requiring massive capital expenditure. Therefore, the trend has been towards fewer producers and a sharing of components; thus the concept known as the 'world car' has developed. Those with aggressive marketing policies and a willingness to adopt new technologies have become the market leaders. In national terms, that is Japan.

In such a scenario there is no way that the Australian motor vehicle industry can sit back and rely on domestic markets without continuing to impose an ever-increasing assistance burden on the Australian community. This means that unless Australia is prepared to pay that price the notion of a totally Australian designed and manufactured vehicle for the domestic market must become history. The only way that notion could be sustained would be through major export activity which, given the lack of free trade and the lag we would have to make up in technology and capital, is practically impossible.

However, there is an answer. Australia has advantages. We have a highly educated population, an abundance of raw material and cheap power. Furthermore, the economic strengths that have allowed Australia to withstand the cost of current protection can equally enable it to cushion change. Production of export volume levels of cars in Australia may be impossible, but there are components which Australia can produce effectively and economically for the world market. Therefore, change must be to the benefit of those who are able to produce an internationally competitive product and thus gain the economies of scale available from long production runs. Those who are prepared to do that must be given an incentive.

The answer lies in the principle of export facilitation. Export facilitition gives credits for exports by allowing a given level of tariff-free imports equivalent in dollar value to goods exported. For those, such as some component manufacturers who are unable to benefit from tariff free imports, it gives an opportunity to transfer the credit and thus gain an advantage. It is obvious, however, that export facilitation will work only if quotas are kept tight and tariffs high; in other words, there must be an inbuilt benefit to exporters within the protection system.

In the longer term the object must be the abolition of quotas or market sharing, which is an undesirable means of protection because it fails to reward or even to encourage efficiency. Tariffs, a more equitable form of protection than quotas, must be reduced to a level more equivalent to tariff protection given to other manufacturing sectors. Current rates of protection, perhaps with the exception of only a gradual reduction of tariffs which would provide some greater competitive pressure, must be the cushion to allow export facilitation to play its role. However, that reduction must be sufficiently gradual not to detract from the inducement of export facilitation. Survival in an ultimately non-quota lower tariff environment must be the penalty for those not prepared to grasp the nettle.

To say that quotas will be dropped after a reasonable period-say, 10 years from the commencement of export facilitation-places a massive political burden on a government for an opposition will seize the short term electoral advantage of offering a reversal of that decision. Nevertheless, it appears to me that there is no alternative. Even within the present scheme there is need for reform of the quota system and for export facilitation. Quotas now are simply a financial gift. The Deutsche mark has devalued against the Australian dollar by 12.8 per cent over the last year, but the price of Mercedes-Benz cars does not appear to have come down. Why should not the Australian manufacturer who is prepared to rationalise and specialise to fewer lines with export potential have an import quota to balance his stock range? Why should not a greater percentage of quotas be auctioned so that at least that revenue can contribute something towards the cost of protection?

Similarly, export facilitation as presently structured should be re-examined because of its dollar for dollar basis and the fact that some Japanese components are two to five times cheaper than the locally made product. It may be that, as submitted by one party to the Commission, 7.5 per cent of imports will be sufficient to displace 21 per cent of local manufacture. If that is so, the scheme as presently structured has the potential to destroy a large part of the component industry without that industry having time to restructure. Furthermore, before quotas are dropped Australia's dumping laws should be re-examined and their effectiveness re-assessed. The Australian industry can regain its lost competitiveness provided it is given time to do so. But there must be both pressures in that direction and rewards for those prepared to meet the challenge. In other words, assistance must be directed towards the long term goal of greater efficiency. A more efficient and export orientated vehicle and component sector which is able to benefit from economies of scale will require less and less government financial support.

However, the picture is not all gloom. There are encouraging signs. Already Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd can claim that in 1976 the Chrysler plant was averaging 69 man hours to make a car. That figure is now 23 hours. Improved management, vehicle design and tooling techniques have led to increased efficiency. The company can further boast that in the 30 months to June 1981, although the consumer price index went up 26 per cent, Sigma car price rises were kept to 17 per cent. The industry can show over $1 billion having recently been or to be spent on capital investment. For example, the Ford company has in train $300m five-year investment program. The new four-cylinder engine plant of General Motors-Holden's Ltd at Fisherman's Bend has cost $300m. Thus, the Australian industry is showing a commitment in this vital area.

In the field of exports there are also pleasing examples of what can be achieved. Girlock has recently won a $100m contract to supply Australian designed brake units for a United States luxury car. GKN Sanky-Benson currently exports wheel rims to Japan. With the benefit of export facilitation, GMH will now produce 300,000 engines, of which 240,000 will be exported. These are examples that show that Australia can become competitive on world markets. What the industry needs is the firm, consistent and realistic hand of government. The industry should be allowed the benefits of export facilitation with the understanding that current levels of artificial protection will ultimately not last. Let us look to alternative incentives such as improved depreciation provisions, grants for industrial research for worthwhile projects and technical aid. Let us head towards an industry which will be efficient by world standards and able to provide security and the rewards of worthwhile employment whilst at the same time enabling growth in other areas that a more efficient redistribution of resources will allow.
